dn14:0.2.eng: The Great Discourse on Traces Left Behind

dn14:1.1.1.comm: In the suttas, apadāna means “evidence”, “traces left behind” (DN 27:16.4, DN 24:2.7.3, MN 15:3.32, AN 3.2:1.1). The sense here seems to have been “(story about) the traces that deeds leave behind”. The sense “legend of past lives” probably grew out of this sutta, and later became the title of the collections of legends of past lives of the monks (Thera-apadāna) and nuns (Therī-apadāna).

dn14:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme karerikuṭikāyaṃ.
dn14:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery, in the hut by the kareri tree.
dn14:1.1.2.comm: Kareri is evidently Miliusa tomentosa, known as hoom or kari in Hindi. It is related to the custard apple, not the curry tree (Murraya koenigii).

dn14:1.1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ karerimaṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ pubbenivāsapaṭisaṃyuttā dhammī kathā udapādi:
dn14:1.1.3.eng: Then after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the pavilion by the kareri tree and this Dhamma talk on the subject of past lives came up among them,

dn14:1.1.4.eng: “So it was in a past life; such it was in a past life.”
dn14:1.1.4.comm: “Past life” is pubbenivāsa, literally “former abode”.

dn14:1.2.1.pli: Assosi kho bhagavā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ imaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ.
dn14:1.2.1.eng: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard that discussion among the mendicants.

dn14:1.2.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena karerimaṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi, nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
dn14:1.2.2.eng: So he got up from his seat and went to the pavilion, where he sat on the seat spread out and addressed the mendicants,

dn14:1.2.3.pli: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā; kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
dn14:1.2.3.eng: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”

dn14:1.2.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn14:1.2.4.eng: The mendicants told him what had happened, adding,

dn14:1.2.5.pli: “idha, bhante, amhākaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ karerimaṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ pubbenivāsapaṭisaṃyuttā dhammī kathā udapādi:

dn14:1.2.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā. Atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
dn14:1.2.7.eng: “This is the conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”

dn14:1.3.1.pli: “Iccheyyātha no tumhe, bhikkhave, pubbenivāsapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ sotun”ti?
dn14:1.3.1.eng: “Would you like to hear a Dhamma talk on the subject of past lives?”

dn14:1.3.2.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

dn14:1.3.3.pli: yaṃ bhagavā pubbenivāsapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ kareyya, bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
dn14:1.3.3.eng: Let the Buddha give a Dhamma talk on the subject of past lives. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

dn14:1.3.4.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha sādhukaṃ manasi karotha bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn14:1.3.4.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

dn14:1.3.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn14:1.4.1.pli: “Ito so, bhikkhave, ekanavutikappe yaṃ vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:1.4.1.eng: “Ninety-one eons ago, the Buddha Vipassī arose in the world, perfected and fully awakened.
dn14:1.4.1.comm: At MN 71:14.2 and SN 42.9:4.5 the Buddha says he recollects ninety-one eons, which must refer back to the life of Vipassī. We shall see the origin of his name below.

dn14:1.4.2.pli: Ito so, bhikkhave, ekatiṃse kappe yaṃ sikhī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:1.4.2.eng: Thirty-one eons ago, the Buddha Sikhī arose in the world, perfected and fully awakened.
dn14:1.4.2.comm: Sikhī means “crested one” and refers to a halo or crown. A story of him and his disciples is told at SN 6.14.

dn14:1.4.3.pli: Tasmiññeva kho, bhikkhave, ekatiṃse kappe vessabhū bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:1.4.3.eng: In the same thirty-first eon, the Buddha Vessabhū arose in the world, perfected and fully awakened.
dn14:1.4.3.comm: Vessabhū is Sanskrit Viśvabhṛt. It means “all-bearing”, probably originating as a word for the earth. A legendary king of the same name once ruled over the city of Avantī (DN 19:36.14).

dn14:1.4.4.pli: Imasmiññeva kho, bhikkhave, bhaddakappe kakusandho bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:1.4.4.eng: In the present fortunate eon, the Buddhas Kakusandha,
dn14:1.4.4.comm: Due to the appearance of four Buddhas in this cycle it is known as “fortunate” (bhadda). | Stories from Kakusandha’s day appear at MN 50 and SN 15.20:2.8. There is no obvious etymology for his name, but perhaps it stems from kaku (“peak”) and thus “the union of the peaks”, a valley at the junction of mountains.

dn14:1.4.5.pli: Imasmiññeva kho, bhikkhave, bhaddakappe koṇāgamano bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:1.4.5.comm: The meaning of Koṇāgamana is unclear. In Sanskrit it is often spelled Kanakamuni, “the golden sage”, while in the (dubious) Nigali Sagar Edict of Ashoka it is Konākamana. At Thig 16.1:71.1 we hear the past life of three nuns in the time of Koṇāgamana.

dn14:1.4.6.pli: Imasmiññeva kho, bhikkhave, bhaddakappe kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:1.4.6.eng: and Kassapa arose in the world, perfected and fully awakened.
dn14:1.4.6.comm: Kassapa (Sanskrit Kaśyapa) means “tortoise”. It is a common Brahmanical clan name, stemming from an ancient figure reckoned as the eldest of the “seven sages”, to whom some Vedic verses are attributed. Details of the Buddha Kassapa’s time are found at MN 81, SN 15.20:4.1, and SN 48.57:3.1.

dn14:1.4.7.pli: Imasmiññeva kho, bhikkhave, bhaddakappe ahaṃ etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno.
dn14:1.4.7.eng: And in the present fortunate eon, I have arisen in the world, perfected and fully awakened.
dn14:1.4.7.comm: These numbers make up a quasi-logarithmic scale: the time gaps multiply by three, while the number of Buddhas divides by two. In eon one there are four Buddhas. Thirty eons ago the number is halved, so they had two Buddhas. Twice-thirty eons before that, the number is halved again, to one Buddha, thus ending the scale.

dn14:1.5.1.pli: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho khattiyo jātiyā ahosi, khattiyakule udapādi.

dn14:1.5.2.pli: Sikhī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho khattiyo jātiyā ahosi, khattiyakule udapādi.

dn14:1.5.3.pli: Vessabhū, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho khattiyo jātiyā ahosi, khattiyakule udapādi.
dn14:1.5.3.eng: and Vessabhū were born as aristocrats into aristocrat families.

dn14:1.5.4.pli: Kakusandho, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho brāhmaṇo jātiyā ahosi, brāhmaṇakule udapādi.

dn14:1.5.5.pli: Koṇāgamano, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho brāhmaṇo jātiyā ahosi, brāhmaṇakule udapādi.

dn14:1.5.6.pli: Kassapo, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho brāhmaṇo jātiyā ahosi, brāhmaṇakule udapādi.
dn14:1.5.6.eng: and Kassapa were born as brahmins into brahmin families.

dn14:1.5.7.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho khattiyo jātiyā ahosiṃ, khattiyakule uppanno.
dn14:1.5.7.eng: I was born as an aristocrat into an aristocrat family.
dn14:1.5.7.comm: In ancient India, the “aristocrats” (khattiya) and the brahmins vied for the prestige of being the highest class. The traditional business of the aristocrats was land, politics, agriculture, and war, while the brahmins were a hereditary priestly caste who served as advisers and ritualists. It is said that the Buddha-to-be was born in whatever caste was most prestigious at the time so that his word would have the most impact. | In this sutta, the Buddha simply refers to himself as “I” with no personal name. When the seven Buddhas are listed at DN 32:3.14, however, he is called Aṅgīrasa.

dn14:1.6.1.pli: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho koṇḍañño gottena ahosi.
dn14:1.6.1.eng: Koṇḍañña was the clan of Vipassī,
dn14:1.6.1.comm: The Koṇḍaññas (Sanskrit Kauṇḍinya) originated as the leading clan of the city of Kuṇḍina the capital of Vidarbha, which is probably modern Kaundinyapura on the Wardha River.

dn14:1.6.2.pli: Sikhī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho koṇḍañño gottena ahosi.

dn14:1.6.3.pli: Vessabhū, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho koṇḍañño gottena ahosi.

dn14:1.6.4.pli: Kakusandho, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kassapo gottena ahosi.
dn14:1.6.4.eng: Kassapa was the clan of Kakusandha,

dn14:1.6.5.pli: Koṇāgamano, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kassapo gottena ahosi.

dn14:1.6.6.pli: Kassapo, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kassapo gottena ahosi.

dn14:1.6.7.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho gotamo gottena ahosiṃ.
dn14:1.6.7.comm: Gotama is an ancient Brahmanical clan name, which like Kassapa stems from the Vedas and the seven sages. Why does the Buddha, an aristocrat, have a Brahmanical clan? During initiation by a Brahmanical family priest (purohita), an aristocrat was ritually determined to be a brahmin for a short time, during which he would assume the lineage name of the priest. After being restored as an aristocrat, he and his family would still be referred to by that name. Thus the Sakyans’ purohita must have been of the Gotama lineage. Other examples of this practice include the Mallas who are called Vāseṭṭha (DN 16:5.19.2) and Saccaka who is called Aggivessana (MN 35:4.2). The Jain Ācārāṅgasūtra 2.15.15 records a similar situation, for while Mahāvīra was, like the Buddha, a khattiya, he was of the Kāśyapa gotta, and various relatives were assigned to Vāsiṣṭha, Kauṇḍinya, and Kauśika.

dn14:1.7.1.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asītivassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
dn14:1.7.1.eng: For Vipassī, the lifespan was 80,000 years.

dn14:1.7.2.pli: Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sattativassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
dn14:1.7.2.eng: For Sikhī, the lifespan was 70,000 years.

dn14:1.7.3.pli: Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa saṭṭhivassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
dn14:1.7.3.eng: For Vessabhū, the lifespan was 60,000 years.

dn14:1.7.4.pli: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa cattālīsavassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
dn14:1.7.4.eng: For Kakusandha, the lifespan was 40,000 years.

dn14:1.7.5.pli: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tiṃsavassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
dn14:1.7.5.eng: For Koṇāgamana, the lifespan was 30,000 years.

dn14:1.7.6.pli: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa vīsativassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.
dn14:1.7.6.eng: For Kassapa, the lifespan was 20,000 years.

dn14:1.7.7.pli: Mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi appakaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ parittaṃ lahukaṃ; yo ciraṃ jīvati, so vassasataṃ appaṃ vā bhiyyo.
dn14:1.7.7.eng: For me at this time the life-span is short, brief, and fleeting. A long life is a hundred years or a little more.

dn14:1.8.1.pli: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pāṭaliyā mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.8.1.eng: Vipassī was awakened at the root of a patala tree.
dn14:1.8.1.comm: Stereospermum chelonoides. Dictionaries of Pali and Sanskrit call this the “trumpet-flower tree”, but that is more commonly used for Oroxylum indicum.

dn14:1.8.2.pli: Sikhī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho puṇḍarīkassa mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.8.2.eng: Sikhī was awakened at the root of a white-mango tree.
dn14:1.8.2.comm: Puṇḍarīka is the white lotus, but here it is the name of a tree. The commentary says this is setamba (“white-mango”). It is not, however, the mango variety known by that name today (Mangifera caesia), which is not found in India.

dn14:1.8.3.pli: Vessabhū, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho sālassa mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.8.3.eng: Vessabhū was awakened at the root of a sal tree.

dn14:1.8.4.pli: Kakusandho, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho sirīsassa mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.8.4.eng: Kakusandha was awakened at the root of a lebbeck tree.
dn14:1.8.4.comm: Albizia lebbeck, sometimes still known by the old name of sirisa. Older sources sometimes call it an acacia.

dn14:1.8.5.pli: Koṇāgamano, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho udumbarassa mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.8.5.eng: Koṇāgamana was awakened at the root of a cluster fig tree.

dn14:1.8.6.pli: Kassapo, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho nigrodhassa mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.8.6.eng: Kassapa was awakened at the root of a banyan tree.

dn14:1.8.7.pli: Ahaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho assatthassa mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.8.7.eng: I was awakened at the root of a peepal tree.
dn14:1.8.7.comm: Ficus religiosa, sacred to Buddhists, Jains, and Hindus alike. Ancient sources referred to it both as assattha (Sanskrit aśvattha) and pippala. Buddhists today simply call it the Bodhi (or Bo) tree.

dn14:1.9.1.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa khaṇḍatissaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.9.1.eng: Vipassī had a fine pair of chief disciples named Khaṇḍa and Tissa.

dn14:1.9.2.pli: Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa abhibhūsambhavaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.9.2.eng: Sikhī had a fine pair of chief disciples named Abhibhū and Sambhava.
dn14:1.9.2.comm: Abhibhū means “Victor”, while Sambhava means “son of Śambhu the blessed”. Śambhu is commonly found in the Rig Veda in the sense, “blessing, benefit”, and became a common name or epithet of gods, etc.

dn14:1.9.3.pli: Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa soṇuttaraṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.9.3.eng: Vessabhū had a fine pair of chief disciples named Soṇa and Uttara.

dn14:1.9.4.pli: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa vidhurasañjīvaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.9.4.eng: Kakusandha had a fine pair of chief disciples named Vidhura and Sañjīva.

dn14:1.9.5.pli: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bhiyyosuttaraṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.9.5.eng: Koṇāgamana had a fine pair of chief disciples named Bhiyyosa and Uttara.

dn14:1.9.6.pli: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tissabhāradvājaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.9.6.eng: Kassapa had a fine pair of chief disciples named Tissa and Bhāradvāja.

dn14:1.9.7.pli: Mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi sāriputtamoggallānaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.9.7.eng: I have a fine pair of chief disciples named Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

dn14:1.10.1.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ. Eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi bhikkhusatasahassaṃ, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi asītibhikkhusahassāni. Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ime tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.10.1.eng: Vipassī had three gatherings of disciples—one of 6,800,000, one of 100,000, and one of 80,000—all of them mendicants who had ended their defilements.
dn14:1.10.1.comm: The number of disciples diminishes as we approach historical time.

dn14:1.10.2.pli: Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ. Eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi bhikkhusatasahassaṃ, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi asītibhikkhusahassāni, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi sattatibhikkhusahassāni. Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ime tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.10.2.eng: Sikhī had three gatherings of disciples—one of 100,000, one of 80,000, and one of 70,000—all of them mendicants who had ended their defilements.

dn14:1.10.3.pli: Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ. Eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi asītibhikkhusahassāni, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi sattatibhikkhusahassāni, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi saṭṭhibhikkhusahassāni. Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ime tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.10.3.eng: Vessabhū had three gatherings of disciples—one of 80,000, one of 70,000, and one of 60,000—all of them mendicants who had ended their defilements.

dn14:1.10.4.pli: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi cattālīsabhikkhusahassāni. Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ayaṃ eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.10.4.eng: Kakusandha had one gathering of disciples—40,000 mendicants who had ended their defilements.

dn14:1.10.5.pli: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi tiṃsabhikkhusahassāni. Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ayaṃ eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.10.5.eng: Koṇāgamana had one gathering of disciples—30,000 mendicants who had ended their defilements.

dn14:1.10.6.pli: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi vīsatibhikkhusahassāni. Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ayaṃ eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.10.6.eng: Kassapa had one gathering of disciples—20,000 mendicants who had ended their defilements.

dn14:1.10.7.pli: Mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni. Mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, ayaṃ eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.10.7.eng: I have had one gathering of disciples—1,250 mendicants who had ended their defilements.
dn14:1.10.7.comm: An extensive journey of the Buddha with 1,250 mendicants is documented in Kd 6, at one point of which occurs the events of the Selasutta (Snp 3.7 and MN 91). The Buddha is also accompanied by 1,250 mendicants in the Sāmaññaphalasutta (DN 2) and the Parosahassasutta (SN 8.8).

dn14:1.11.1.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asoko nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.11.1.eng: Vipassī had as chief attendant a mendicant named Asoka.

dn14:1.11.2.pli: Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa khemaṅkaro nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.11.2.eng: Sikhī had as chief attendant a mendicant named Khemaṅkara.

dn14:1.11.3.pli: Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa upasanto nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.11.3.eng: Vessabhū had as chief attendant a mendicant named Upasanta.

dn14:1.11.4.pli: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa buddhijo nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.11.4.eng: Kakusandha had as chief attendant a mendicant named Buddhija.

dn14:1.11.5.pli: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sotthijo nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.11.5.eng: Koṇāgamana had as chief attendant a mendicant named Sotthija.

dn14:1.11.6.pli: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sabbamitto nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.11.6.eng: Kassapa had as chief attendant a mendicant named Sabbamitta.

dn14:1.11.7.pli: Mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi ānando nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.11.7.eng: I have as chief attendant a mendicant named Ānanda.

dn14:1.12.1.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bandhumā nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.1.comm: Bandhumā literally means “one who has kin”. A King Bandhumant is recorded as a descendant of Ikṣvāku, son of Manu, son of the Sun (Viṣṇu Purāṇa 4.1). Gotama, likewise, was a “kinsman of the sun” (ādiccabandhu).

dn14:1.12.2.pli: Bandhumatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.12.2.eng: his birth mother was Queen Bandhumatī,

dn14:1.12.3.pli: Bandhumassa rañño bandhumatī nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:1.12.3.eng: and their capital city was named Bandhumatī.

dn14:1.12.4.pli: Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa aruṇo nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.4.comm: The son of King Dawn and Queen Radiant in the City of the Dawn, Sikhī is the streaming rays of sunrise. These names recall a solar myth.

dn14:1.12.5.pli: Pabhāvatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.12.5.eng: his birth mother was Queen Pabhāvatī,
dn14:1.12.5.comm: In Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa ch. 131, a Pabhāvatī, daughter of the king of Vidarbha, is said to have married Marutta, king of Vajjī.

dn14:1.12.6.pli: Aruṇassa rañño aruṇavatī nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:1.12.6.eng: and their capital city was named Aruṇavatī.
dn14:1.12.6.comm: There is an Arunawati River in Maharashtra, not far from the ancient homeland of the Koṇḍaññas in Kuṇḍina.

dn14:1.12.7.pli: Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa suppatito nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.7.comm: Vessabhū’s parents King Goodfall and Queen Rainy recall a seasonal fertility myth, where they gave life to their son the earth, “the nourisher and bearer of all”. Note, however the variants suppatīta (“well pleased”) and yasavatī (“celebrated”).

dn14:1.12.8.pli: Vassavatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.12.8.eng: his birth mother was Queen Vassavatī,

dn14:1.12.9.pli: Suppatitassa rañño anomaṃ nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:1.12.9.eng: and their capital city was named Anoma.

dn14:1.12.10.pli: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa aggidatto nāma brāhmaṇo pitā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.10.eng: Kakusandha’s father was the brahmin Aggidatta,
dn14:1.12.10.comm: The names of the brahmin fathers all refer to ritual offerings. Aggidatta means “offered to the fire”.

dn14:1.12.11.pli: Visākhā nāma brāhmaṇī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.12.11.eng: and his birth mother was the brahmin lady Visākhā.
dn14:1.12.11.comm: The names of the brahmin mothers all recall Indian nakkhatta. These are “constellations” or more properly “lunar mansions”; segments of the sky through which the Moon passes and which are associated with certain stars or clusters. In the Atharvaveda system, Visākhā is the 16th lunar asterism (Libra).

dn14:1.12.12.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena khemo nāma rājā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.12.eng: At that time the king was Khema,

dn14:1.12.13.pli: Khemassa rañño khemavatī nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:1.12.13.eng: whose capital city was named Khemavatī.
dn14:1.12.13.comm: Based on the Ashoka pillar there, this is identified with modern Gotihawa, southeast of Kapilavastu in Nepal.

dn14:1.12.14.pli: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa yaññadatto nāma brāhmaṇo pitā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.14.eng: Koṇāgamana’s father was the brahmin Yaññadatta,

dn14:1.12.15.pli: Uttarā nāma brāhmaṇī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.12.15.eng: and his birth mother was the brahmin lady Uttarā.
dn14:1.12.15.comm: Several constellations are distinguished as “former” (pubba) and “later” (uttara). Since it lies between Visākhā and Dhanavatī, this may be the 21st constellation, Uttara Āṣāḍhā (Sagittarius/Capricorn).

dn14:1.12.16.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena sobho nāma rājā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.16.eng: At that time the king was Sobha,

dn14:1.12.17.pli: Sobhassa rañño sobhavatī nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:1.12.17.eng: whose capital city was named Sobhavatī.
dn14:1.12.17.comm: If the dubious Ashokan edict there is to be believed, this was traditionally identified with the town known today as Nigali Sagar near Kapilavastu in Nepal.

dn14:1.12.18.pli: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa brahmadatto nāma brāhmaṇo pitā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.18.eng: Kassapa’s father was the brahmin Brahmadatta,
dn14:1.12.18.comm: “Offered to Brahmā”. Many of the Jātakas feature a king of this name, usually said to reside in Benares.

dn14:1.12.19.pli: Dhanavatī nāma brāhmaṇī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.12.19.eng: and his birth mother was the brahmin lady Dhanavatī.
dn14:1.12.19.comm: Dhanavatī means “wealthy”, but it is also an alternate name for the 23rd constellation, dhaniṣṭhā (or śraviṣṭā, Delphinus).

dn14:1.12.20.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena kikī nāma rājā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.20.eng: At that time the king was Kikī,
dn14:1.12.20.comm: Kikī (“blue jay”) appears in the story of the past Buddha Kassapa at MN 81.

dn14:1.12.21.pli: Kikissa rañño bārāṇasī nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:1.12.21.eng: whose capital city was named Varanasi.

dn14:1.12.22.pli: Mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, etarahi suddhodano nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
dn14:1.12.22.eng: In this life, my father was King Suddhodana,
dn14:1.12.22.comm: Suddhodana means “white rice”. He is mentioned by name at Thag 10.1:8.1, Snp 3.11:7.2, and Kd 1:54.1.4.

dn14:1.12.23.pli: Māyā nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.12.23.eng: my birth mother was Queen Māyā,
dn14:1.12.23.comm: Māyā means “illusion”. She is mentioned by name at Thag 10.1:8.2 and Thig 6.6:6.2.

dn14:1.12.24.eng: and our capital city was Kapilavatthu.”

dn14:1.12.25.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn14:1.12.26.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
dn14:1.12.26.eng: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

dn14:1.13.1.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato ayamantarākathā udapādi:
dn14:1.13.1.eng: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants discussed among themselves:

dn14:1.13.2.pli: “acchariyaṃ, āvuso, abbhutaṃ, āvuso, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.
dn14:1.13.2.eng: “It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!

dn14:1.13.3.pli: Yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarissati, nāmatopi anussarissati, gottatopi anussarissati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarissati, sāvakayugatopi anussarissati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarissati:
dn14:1.13.3.eng: For he is able to recollect the birth, names, clans, lifespan, chief disciples, and gatherings of disciples of the Buddhas of the past who have become fully quenched, cut off proliferation, cut off the course, finished off the cycle, and passed beyond all suffering.
dn14:1.13.3.comm: This is the only doctrinal context where we find vaṭuma (“course”). The commentary explains it as the “course of craving”. However, in Buddhist Sanskrit we find the phrases chinnaṃ vartmaṃ na vartati (Mahāvastu 2.416) and chinnaṃ vartma na pravartate (Nidāna Saṁyukta 11.6), which recall the Pali phrase vaṭṭaṁ vattati (DN 15:22.6), where vaṭṭa occurs in the next word of the current passage. This suggests that the sense is, rather, the “course of transmigration”, as in the later Sanskrit phrase saṁsāravartmani.

dn14:1.13.4.pli: ‘evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī’”ti.
dn14:1.13.4.eng: He knows their birth, names, clans, conduct, qualities, wisdom, meditation, and freedom.

dn14:1.13.5.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, tathāgatasseva nu kho esā dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: ‘evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī’ti,
dn14:1.13.5.eng: Is it because the Realized One has clearly comprehended the principle of the teachings that he can recollect all these things?
dn14:1.13.5.comm: “Principle of the teachings” is dhammadhātu. At SN 12.32:18.1, Sāriputta’s mastery of the dhammadhātu gives him the ability to answer any questions on the Dhamma.

dn14:1.13.6.pli: udāhu devatā tathāgatassa etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: ‘evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī’”ti.

dn14:1.13.7.pli: Ayañca hidaṃ tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ antarākathā vippakatā hoti.
dn14:1.13.7.eng: But this conversation among those mendicants was left unfinished.

dn14:1.14.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena karerimaṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn14:1.14.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the pavilion by the kareri tree, where he sat on the seat spread out

dn14:1.14.3.pli: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā; kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
dn14:1.14.3.eng: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”

dn14:1.14.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn14:1.14.4.eng: The mendicants told him what had happened, adding,

dn14:1.14.5.pli: “idha, bhante, amhākaṃ acirapakkantassa bhagavato ayaṃ antarākathā udapādi:

dn14:1.14.6.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ, āvuso, abbhutaṃ, āvuso, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.

dn14:1.14.7.pli: Yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarissati, nāmatopi anussarissati, gottatopi anussarissati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarissati, sāvakayugatopi anussarissati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarissati:

dn14:1.14.8.pli: “evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī”ti.

dn14:1.14.9.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, tathāgatasseva nu kho esā dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:

dn14:1.14.10.pli: “evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī”ti.

dn14:1.14.11.pli: Udāhu devatā tathāgatassa etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:

dn14:1.14.12.pli: “evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī”’ti?

dn14:1.14.13.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
dn14:1.14.13.eng: “This was our conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”

dn14:1.15.1.pli: “Tathāgatassevesā, bhikkhave, dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:
dn14:1.15.1.eng: “It is because the Realized One has clearly comprehended the principle of the teachings that he can recollect all these things.

dn14:1.15.2.pli: ‘evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī’ti.

dn14:1.15.3.pli: Devatāpi tathāgatassa etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:
dn14:1.15.3.eng: And the deities also told me.

dn14:1.15.4.pli: ‘evaṃjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃnāmā evaṅgottā evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī’ti.

dn14:1.15.5.pli: Iccheyyātha no tumhe, bhikkhave, bhiyyoso mattāya pubbenivāsapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ sotun”ti?
dn14:1.15.5.eng: Would you like to hear a further Dhamma talk on the subject of past lives?”

dn14:1.15.6.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

dn14:1.15.7.pli: yaṃ bhagavā bhiyyoso mattāya pubbenivāsapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ kareyya, bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
dn14:1.15.7.eng: Let the Buddha give a further Dhamma talk on the subject of past lives. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

dn14:1.15.8.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn14:1.15.8.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

dn14:1.15.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn14:1.16.1.pli: “Ito so, bhikkhave, ekanavutikappe yaṃ vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:1.16.1.eng: “Ninety-one eons ago, the Buddha Vipassī arose in the world, perfected and fully awakened.

dn14:1.16.2.pli: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho khattiyo jātiyā ahosi, khattiyakule udapādi.
dn14:1.16.2.eng: He was born as an aristocrat into an aristocrat family.

dn14:1.16.3.pli: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho koṇḍañño gottena ahosi.

dn14:1.16.4.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asītivassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.

dn14:1.16.5.pli: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pāṭaliyā mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:1.16.5.eng: He was awakened at the root of a patala tree.

dn14:1.16.6.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa khaṇḍatissaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:1.16.6.eng: He had a fine pair of chief disciples named Khaṇḍa and Tissa.

dn14:1.16.7.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ.
dn14:1.16.7.eng: He had three gatherings of disciples—

dn14:1.16.8.pli: Eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi bhikkhusatasahassaṃ, eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi asītibhikkhusahassāni.
dn14:1.16.8.eng: one of 6,800,000, one of 100,000, and one of 80,000—

dn14:1.16.9.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ime tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:1.16.9.eng: all of them mendicants who had ended their defilements.

dn14:1.16.10.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asoko nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:1.16.10.eng: He had as chief attendant a mendicant named Asoka.

dn14:1.16.11.pli: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bandhumā nāma rājā pitā ahosi.

dn14:1.16.12.pli: Bandhumatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:1.16.12.eng: his birth mother was Queen Bandhumatī,

dn14:1.16.13.pli: Bandhumassa rañño bandhumatī nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:1.16.13.eng: and their capital city was named Bandhumatī.

dn14:1.17.0.eng: 2. What’s Normal For One Intent on Awakening

dn14:1.17.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bodhisatto tusitā kāyā cavitvā sato sampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkami.
dn14:1.17.1.eng: When Vipassī, the being intent on awakening, passed away from the host of joyful gods, he was conceived in his mother’s womb, mindful and aware.
dn14:1.17.1.comm: These characteristics of the birth of the Buddha-to-be are also found in MN 123, where Ānanda quotes the Buddha, although the wording is a little different and three extra details are added at the start. In addition, this detail and that about emerging mindfully from the womb are found at AN 4.127. | Normally in early Pali, the word bodhisatta is reserved for the Buddha-to-be once he has left home and is practicing “intent on awakening” (eg. MN 26:13.1). This passage extends the usage back as far as the end of the immediate past life.

dn14:1.17.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.
dn14:1.17.2.comm: “Normal” is dhammatā, a natural principle. This entire passage differs from the earliest concept of the bodhisatta (“one intent on awakening”), which in early texts is typically applied to Siddhattha after he left the home.

dn14:1.17.3.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto tusitā kāyā cavitvā mātukucchiṃ okkamati.
dn14:1.17.3.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening passes away from the host of joyful gods, he is conceived in his mother’s womb.

dn14:1.17.4.pli: Atha sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
dn14:1.17.4.eng: And then—in this world with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods.

dn14:1.17.5.pli: Yāpi tā lokantarikā aghā asaṃvutā andhakārā andhakāratimisā, yatthapime candimasūriyā evaṃmahiddhikā evaṃmahānubhāvā ābhāya nānubhonti, tatthapi appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
dn14:1.17.5.eng: Even in the boundless gloom of interstellar space—so utterly dark that even the luminosity of the moon and the sun, so mighty and powerful, makes no impression—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods.
dn14:1.17.5.comm: The commentary identifies this realm of “utter darkness” (andhakāratimisā) with a cold hell realm. There is a corresponding Purāṇic hell called andhatāmisra. | Asaṁvutā was translated by Ñāṇamoḷī as “abysmal”, but this relies on a commentarial cosmology that is not found in the suttas. The sense, rather, is “boundless”. The root harks back to the Vedic serpent Vṛtra who wraps the world in darkness. | Nānubhonti (“makes no impression”) is glossed in the commentary to AN 4.127 as nappahonti “ineffective”.

dn14:1.17.6.pli: Yepi tattha sattā upapannā, tepi tenobhāsena aññamaññaṃ sañjānanti: ‘aññepi kira, bho, santi sattā idhūpapannā’ti.
dn14:1.17.6.eng: And the sentient beings reborn there recognize each other by that light: ‘So, it seems other sentient beings have been reborn here!’
dn14:1.17.6.comm: The light is a physical one, not just a metaphor. From this, it appears that sentient beings may be spontaneously reborn in interstellar space. Compare the problem of the “Boltzmann brain” in physics.

dn14:1.17.7.pli: Ayañca dasasahassī lokadhātu saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati. Appamāṇo ca uḷāro obhāso loke pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
dn14:1.17.7.eng: And this ten-thousandfold galaxy shakes and rocks and trembles. And an immeasurable, magnificent light appears in the world, surpassing the glory of the gods.

dn14:1.17.8.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.17.9.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṃ okkanto hoti, cattāro naṃ devaputtā catuddisaṃ rakkhāya upagacchanti: ‘mā naṃ bodhisattaṃ vā bodhisattamātaraṃ vā manusso vā amanusso vā koci vā viheṭhesī’ti.
dn14:1.17.9.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, four godlings approach to guard the four quarters, so that no human or non-human or anyone at all shall harm the being intent on awakening or his mother.
dn14:1.17.9.comm: These are the Four Great Kings, regarded as protector deities. | The term okkanti (“conception”) is a synonym of “rebirth” (DN 15:4.3). It literally means “descent”. Its usage in this context is anticipated by Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.1, which describes how, as a man is dying, his self “descends” into the heart. He loses sense awareness, the tip of his heart lights up and he departs, “rising” (utkrāmanta) with his life-breath, and “descending” with consciousness into a new life, taking his knowledge, deeds, and past experiences.

dn14:1.17.10.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.18.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṃ okkanto hoti, pakatiyā sīlavatī bodhisattamātā hoti, viratā pāṇātipātā, viratā adinnādānā, viratā kāmesumicchācārā, viratā musāvādā, viratā surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā.
dn14:1.18.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, she becomes naturally ethical. She refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

dn14:1.18.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.19.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṃ okkanto hoti, na bodhisattamātu purisesu mānasaṃ uppajjati kāmaguṇūpasaṃhitaṃ, anatikkamanīyā ca bodhisattamātā hoti kenaci purisena rattacittena.
dn14:1.19.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, she no longer thinks of men in a sexual way, and she cannot be violated by a man of lustful intent.

dn14:1.19.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.20.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṃ okkanto hoti, lābhinī bodhisattamātā hoti pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ. Sā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricāreti.
dn14:1.20.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, she obtains the five kinds of sensual stimulation and amuses herself, supplied and provided with them.
dn14:1.20.1.comm: While sensual pleasures provoke attachment, they are nonetheless a kind of pleasure and therefore a sign of virtue and good past kamma.

dn14:1.20.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.21.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṃ okkanto hoti, na bodhisattamātu kocideva ābādho uppajjati. Sukhinī bodhisattamātā hoti akilantakāyā, bodhisattañca bodhisattamātā tirokucchigataṃ passati sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriyaṃ.
dn14:1.21.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, no afflictions beset her. She’s happy and free of bodily fatigue. And she sees the being intent on awakening in her womb, whole in his major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.

dn14:1.21.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatrāssa suttaṃ āvutaṃ nīlaṃ vā pītaṃ vā lohitaṃ vā odātaṃ vā paṇḍusuttaṃ vā.
dn14:1.21.2.eng: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities. And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.

dn14:1.21.3.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya: ‘ayaṃ kho maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatridaṃ suttaṃ āvutaṃ nīlaṃ vā pītaṃ vā lohitaṃ vā odātaṃ vā paṇḍusuttaṃ vā’ti.
dn14:1.21.3.eng: And a person with clear eyes were to take it in their hand and examine it: ‘This beryl gem is naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities. And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.’

dn14:1.21.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṃ okkanto hoti, na bodhisattamātu kocideva ābādho uppajjati, sukhinī bodhisattamātā hoti akilantakāyā, bodhisattañca bodhisattamātā tirokucchigataṃ passati sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriyaṃ.
dn14:1.21.4.eng: In the same way, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, no afflictions beset her. She’s happy and free of bodily fatigue. And she sees the being intent on awakening in her womb, whole in his major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.

dn14:1.21.5.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.22.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, sattāhajāte bodhisatte bodhisattamātā kālaṃ karoti tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapajjati.
dn14:1.22.1.eng: It’s normal that, seven days after the being intent on awakening is born, his mother passes away and is reborn in the host of joyful gods.
dn14:1.22.1.comm: This tragic detail is also mentioned in Ud 5.2. The Buddha is raised by a step-mother, which in our Buddha’s case was Māyā’s sister Mahāpajāpatī (AN 8.51:9.8, MN 142:3.3).

dn14:1.22.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.23.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yathā aññā itthikā nava vā dasa vā māse gabbhaṃ kucchinā pariharitvā vijāyanti, na hevaṃ bodhisattaṃ bodhisattamātā vijāyati. Daseva māsāni bodhisattaṃ bodhisattamātā kucchinā pariharitvā vijāyati.
dn14:1.23.1.eng: It’s normal that, while other women carry the infant in the womb for nine or ten months before giving birth, not so the mother of the being intent on awakening. She gives birth after exactly ten months.
dn14:1.23.1.comm: Ten signifies fullness and completion, as for example the “ten directions”. | The notion that the term of pregnancy was “nine or ten months” is also found at Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.9.1. In the Rig Veda it is typically “in the tenth month” (5.78.7, 10.84.3), as also at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.22.

dn14:1.23.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.24.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yathā aññā itthikā nisinnā vā nipannā vā vijāyanti, na hevaṃ bodhisattaṃ bodhisattamātā vijāyati. Ṭhitāva bodhisattaṃ bodhisattamātā vijāyati.
dn14:1.24.1.eng: It’s normal that, while other women give birth while sitting or lying down, not so the mother of the being intent on awakening. She only gives birth standing up.
dn14:1.24.1.comm: In illustrations she is depicted standing while holding a tree in the pose known as sālabhañjikā, a common motif in Indian art representing the abundance of springtime.

dn14:1.24.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.25.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, devā paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhanti, pacchā manussā.
dn14:1.25.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, gods receive him first, then humans.

dn14:1.25.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.26.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, appattova bodhisatto pathaviṃ hoti, cattāro naṃ devaputtā paṭiggahetvā mātu purato ṭhapenti: ‘attamanā, devi, hohi; mahesakkho te putto uppanno’ti.
dn14:1.26.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, before he reaches the ground, four godlings receive him and place him before his mother, saying: ‘Rejoice, O Queen! An illustrious son is born to you.’

dn14:1.26.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.27.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, visadova nikkhamati amakkhito udena amakkhito semhena amakkhito ruhirena amakkhito kenaci asucinā suddho visado.
dn14:1.27.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, he emerges already clean, unsoiled by waters, mucus, blood, or any other kind of impurity, pure and clean.

dn14:1.27.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, maṇiratanaṃ kāsike vatthe nikkhittaṃ neva maṇiratanaṃ kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ makkheti, nāpi kāsikaṃ vatthaṃ maṇiratanaṃ makkheti.
dn14:1.27.2.eng: Suppose a jewel-treasure was placed on a cloth from Kāsi. The jewel would not soil the cloth, nor would the cloth soil the jewel.
dn14:1.27.2.comm: Kāsi is the nation of which Varanasi is the capital. Their cloth was of exceptional quality.

dn14:1.27.4.eng: Because of the cleanliness of them both.

dn14:1.27.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, visadova nikkhamati amakkhito, udena amakkhito semhena amakkhito ruhirena amakkhito kenaci asucinā suddho visado.
dn14:1.27.5.eng: In the same way, when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, he emerges already clean, unsoiled by waters, mucus, blood, or any other kind of impurity, pure and clean.

dn14:1.27.6.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.28.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, dve udakassa dhārā antalikkhā pātubhavanti—ekā sītassa ekā uṇhassa yena bodhisattassa udakakiccaṃ karonti mātu ca.
dn14:1.28.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, two showers of water appear from the sky, one cool, one warm, for bathing the being intent on awakening and his mother.

dn14:1.28.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.29.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, sampatijāto bodhisatto samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahitvā uttarābhimukho sattapadavītihārena gacchati setamhi chatte anudhāriyamāne, sabbā ca disā anuviloketi, āsabhiṃ vācaṃ bhāsati ‘aggohamasmi lokassa, jeṭṭhohamasmi lokassa, seṭṭhohamasmi lokassa, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’ti.
dn14:1.29.1.eng: It’s normal that, as soon as he’s born, the being intent on awakening stands firm with his own feet on the ground. Facing north, he takes seven strides with a white parasol held above him, surveys all quarters, and makes this dramatic proclamation: ‘I am the foremost in the world! I am the eldest in the world! I am the first in the world! This is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
dn14:1.29.1.comm: This passage implies that Buddhahood was destined from the time of birth, which stands in contrast to the rest of the suttas, where Buddhahood was hard-won by the Bodhisatta’s efforts while striving for awakening. | “Stands firm on his own feet” signifies that he will be awakened by his own efforts. | “North” is uttara, which is also “the beyond”; this predicts his attaining Nibbana. | “Seven strides” signifies crossing over the vast cycles of birth and death, especially by developing the seven awakening factors. | The “white parasol” signifies purity and royalty. | “Surveying all quarters” signifies his universal knowledge. | The “dramatic proclamation” is āsabhiṁ vācaṁ, literally the “voice of a bull”. Other contexts show that this is is an expression emphasizing speech that is dramatic and imposing (SN 52.9:3.2, DN 28:1.5 = SN 47.12:5.2). | At Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.1.1 and Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.1.1 the “vital breath” (prāṇa) is said to be “eldest and first” (jyeṣṭhaśca śreṣṭhaśca).

dn14:1.29.2.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.30.1.pli: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, atha sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati, atikkammeva devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
dn14:1.30.1.eng: It’s normal that, when the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, then—in this world with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods.

dn14:1.30.2.pli: Yāpi tā lokantarikā aghā asaṃvutā andhakārā andhakāratimisā, yatthapime candimasūriyā evaṃmahiddhikā evaṃmahānubhāvā ābhāya nānubhonti, tatthapi appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
dn14:1.30.2.eng: Even in the boundless gloom of interstellar space—so utterly dark that even the luminosity of the moon and the sun, so mighty and powerful, makes no impression—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods.

dn14:1.30.3.pli: Yepi tattha sattā upapannā, tepi tenobhāsena aññamaññaṃ sañjānanti: ‘aññepi kira, bho, santi sattā idhūpapannā’ti.
dn14:1.30.3.eng: And the sentient beings reborn there recognize each other by that light: ‘So, it seems other sentient beings have been reborn here!’

dn14:1.30.4.pli: Ayañca dasasahassī lokadhātu saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati appamāṇo ca uḷāro obhāso loke pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
dn14:1.30.4.eng: And this ten-thousandfold galaxy shakes and rocks and trembles. And an immeasurable, magnificent light appears in the world, surpassing the glory of the gods.

dn14:1.30.5.eng: This is normal in such a case.

dn14:1.31.0.eng: 3. The Thirty-Two Marks of a Great Man

dn14:1.31.1.pli: Jāte kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassimhi kumāre bandhumato rañño paṭivedesuṃ:
dn14:1.31.1.eng: When Prince Vipassī was born, they announced it to King Bandhumā,
dn14:1.31.1.comm: Many of the details of the following account were later incorporated into the life of Gotama, under the principle that the major events of the lives of Buddhas follow a natural order. Nonetheless, they are not always consistent with other accounts in early texts. For example, in the Attadaṇḍasutta the Buddha says his going forth was prompted by disillusionment and fear due to chronic conflict and warfare (Snp 4.15).

dn14:1.31.2.pli: ‘putto te, deva, jāto, taṃ devo passatū’ti.
dn14:1.31.2.eng: ‘Sire, your son is born! Let your majesty examine him!’

dn14:1.31.3.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā vipassiṃ kumāraṃ, disvā nemitte brāhmaṇe āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
dn14:1.31.3.eng: When the king had examined the prince, he had the brahmin soothsayers summoned and said to them,
dn14:1.31.3.comm: In Snp 3.11, the newborn Siddhattha is examined by the dark hermit Asita. These two versions are combined in later accounts.

dn14:1.31.5.pli: Addasaṃsu kho, bhikkhave, nemittā brāhmaṇā vipassiṃ kumāraṃ, disvā bandhumantaṃ rājānaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn14:1.31.5.eng: When they had examined him they said to the king,

dn14:1.31.6.pli: ‘attamano, deva, hohi, mahesakkho te putto uppanno, lābhā te, mahārāja, suladdhaṃ te, mahārāja, yassa te kule evarūpo putto uppanno.
dn14:1.31.6.eng: ‘Rejoice, O King! An illustrious son is born to you. You are fortunate, so very fortunate, to have a son such as this born in this family!

dn14:1.31.7.pli: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
dn14:1.31.7.eng: For the prince possesses the thirty-two marks of a great man. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
dn14:1.31.7.comm: Asita did not look at the 32 marks, and he predicted only one destiny: that he would become a Buddha.

dn14:1.31.8.pli: Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
dn14:1.31.8.eng: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.

dn14:1.31.9.eng: He has the following seven treasures:
dn14:1.31.9.comm: Various “treasures” (ratana) or “gems” of a king are discussed in such texts as Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.3.1.

dn14:1.31.10.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—cakkaratanaṃ hatthiratanaṃ assaratanaṃ maṇiratanaṃ itthiratanaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.
dn14:1.31.10.eng: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.

dn14:1.31.11.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
dn14:1.31.11.eng: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

dn14:1.31.12.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
dn14:1.31.12.eng: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

dn14:1.31.13.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭacchado.
dn14:1.31.13.eng: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.

dn14:1.32.1.pli: Katamehi cāyaṃ, deva, kumāro dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
dn14:1.32.1.eng: And what are the marks which he possesses?
dn14:1.32.1.comm: The marks are elsewhere listed in DN 30:1.2.1 and MN 91:9.1. Here I list the related marks in the Bṛhatsaṁhitā as identified by Nathan McGovern (On the Origins of the 32 Marks of a Great Man, Journal of the International Association of Buddhist Studies, 2016, vol. 39, pp. 207–247).

dn14:1.32.2.pli: Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.

dn14:1.32.4.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—cakkaratanaṃ hatthiratanaṃ assaratanaṃ maṇiratanaṃ itthiratanaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.

dn14:1.32.5.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.

dn14:1.32.6.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.

dn14:1.32.7.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭacchado. Ayañhi, deva, kumāro suppatiṭṭhitapādo. Yaṃ pāyaṃ, deva, kumāro suppatiṭṭhitapādo. Idampissa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.
dn14:1.32.7.comm: This echoes the posture of the newborn bodhisatta, and has the same meaning: that he will become awakened by “standing on his own two feet”.

dn14:1.32.8.pli: Imassa, deva, kumārassa heṭṭhā pādatalesu cakkāni jātāni sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni. Yampi imassa, deva, kumārassa heṭṭhā pādatalesu cakkāni jātāni sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni, idampissa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.
dn14:1.32.8.eng: On the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail.
dn14:1.32.8.comm: These leave marks that were seen by Doṇa (AN 4.36:1.3). They are often depicted in Buddhist art, signifying the perfection and completeness of the traces that the Buddha leaves behind in his teachings and practice. Bṛhatsaṁhitā 69.17 lists several auspicious marks, including the wheel.

dn14:1.32.11.eng: His hands and feet are tender.

dn14:1.32.12.eng: He has serried hands and feet.
dn14:1.32.12.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.2 has śliṣtāṅgulī (“compact or sticky fingers”). The commentary denies that the Pali jāla means a physical web. I think it means that the fingers and toes were usually held together rather than splayed, hence not letting things slip through the fingers.

dn14:1.32.13.eng: The tops of his feet are arched.
dn14:1.32.13.comm: Ussaṅkha means “(curved) up like a shell”, while Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.2 says “curved up like a tortoise”. The descriptive verse at DN 30:1.21.12 shows that it refers to the tops of the feet.

dn14:1.32.14.eng: His calves are like those of an antelope.
dn14:1.32.14.comm: These are presumably the long, elegant rear calves of the Indian Blackbuck.

dn14:1.32.15.pli: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro ṭhitakova anonamanto ubhohi pāṇitalehi jaṇṇukāni parimasati parimajjati …pe…
dn14:1.32.15.eng: When standing upright and not bending over, the palms of both hands touch the knees.

dn14:1.32.16.eng: His private parts are covered in a foreskin.

dn14:1.32.17.eng: He is golden colored; his skin shines like lustrous gold.
dn14:1.32.17.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.102 says kings have a shining complexion.

dn14:1.32.18.pli: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro sukhumacchavī; sukhumattā chaviyā rajojallaṃ kāye na upalimpati …pe…
dn14:1.32.18.eng: He has delicate skin, so delicate that dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.
dn14:1.32.18.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.102 mentions a “clean complexion” (śuddha).

dn14:1.32.19.pli: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro ekekalomo; ekekāni lomāni lomakūpesu jātāni …pe…
dn14:1.32.19.eng: His hairs grow one per pore.

dn14:1.32.20.pli: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro uddhaggalomo; uddhaggāni lomāni jātāni nīlāni añjanavaṇṇāni kuṇḍalāvaṭṭāni dakkhiṇāvaṭṭakajātāni …pe…
dn14:1.32.20.eng: His hairs stand up; they’re blue-black and curl clockwise.
dn14:1.32.20.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.26 says those with hairs turning right become kings.

dn14:1.32.21.eng: His body is tall and straight-limbed.
dn14:1.32.21.comm: Here brahm- is an adjective from √brah + ma, equivalent to the Sanskrit bṛṁh, having the sense “grown, extended”. The Sanskrit form here is bṛhadṛjugātra.

dn14:1.32.22.eng: He has bulging muscles in seven places.
dn14:1.32.22.comm: Hands, feet, shoulders, and chest (DN 30:1.13.5).

dn14:1.32.23.eng: His chest is like that of a lion.
dn14:1.32.23.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.18 compares not the chest but the hips with a lion.

dn14:1.32.24.eng: He is filled out between the shoulders.
dn14:1.32.24.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.27 says the heart is raised and muscular.

dn14:1.32.25.pli: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo yāvatakvassa kāyo tāvatakvassa byāmo, yāvatakvassa byāmo, tāvatakvassa kāyo …pe…
dn14:1.32.25.eng: He has the proportional circumference of a banyan tree: the span of his arms equals the height of his body.
dn14:1.32.25.comm: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 69.13 has the same proportions without the simile. These are the normal human proportions, yet we cannot touch our knees without bending. The only way these marks could be reconciled is if the arms were extra long and the length of the legs below the knees was extra long as well. And this is exactly what we are told: the ankles are stretched and long, and the calves are like those of an antelope, whose rear calves are long proportionate to the thigh. Thus in this regard the marks appear to be internally consistent, though not describing normal human anatomy.

dn14:1.32.27.comm: “Ridged taste buds” is rasaggasaggī. Rasa can mean either “taste” or “nutrition”, but the use of ojā in DN 30:2.9.8 confirms the latter. Gasa is “swallow” and per DN 30:2.7.4 it is the “conveyance of savor” (rasaharaṇīyo). Agga often means “best”, but this is derived from the primary sense of “peak”. The descriptors uddhagga (“raised”) at DN 30:2.7.4 and susaṇṭhitā (“prominent”) at DN 30:2.9.8 confirm that the latter is meant. The mark refers to taste buds raised in noticeable ridges on the tongue that absorb nutrition and aid digestion. It has often been interpreted as “excellent (aggī) sense (gasa) of taste (rasa)”, but this, being imperceptible to others, is rather a secondary consequence of the mark.

dn14:1.32.28.eng: His jaw is like that of a lion.

dn14:1.32.30.comm: Even, gapless, and white teeth are at Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.52.

dn14:1.32.34.eng: He has the voice of the Divinity, like a cuckoo’s call.

dn14:1.32.35.comm: At Thig 13.1:6.2 Ambapālī describes her eyes as abhinīla. While some Indians do indeed have blue eyes, this probably describes a black so deep it appears blue.

dn14:1.32.36.eng: He has eyelashes like a cow’s.
dn14:1.32.36.comm: Cows have long and elegant eyelashes.

dn14:1.32.37.pli: Imassa, deva, kumārassa uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā odātā mudutūlasannibhā. Yampi imassa, deva, kumārassa uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā odātā mudutūlasannibhā, idampimassa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.
dn14:1.32.37.eng: Between his eyebrows there grows a tuft, soft and white like cotton-wool.

dn14:1.32.38.pli: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro uṇhīsasīso. Yaṃ pāyaṃ, deva, kumāro uṇhīsasīso, idampissa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.
dn14:1.32.38.eng: The crown of his head is like a turban.
dn14:1.32.38.comm: The uṇhīsa is depicted as a bulge on the Buddha’s crown.

dn14:1.33.1.pli: Imehi kho ayaṃ, deva, kumāro dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
dn14:1.33.1.eng: These are the thirty-two marks of a great man that the prince has. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.

dn14:1.33.2.pli: Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
dn14:1.33.2.eng: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch.

dn14:1.33.4.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—cakkaratanaṃ hatthiratanaṃ assaratanaṃ maṇiratanaṃ itthiratanaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.

dn14:1.33.5.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.

dn14:1.33.6.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.

dn14:1.33.7.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭacchado’ti.
dn14:1.33.7.eng: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.’

dn14:1.33.8.0.eng: 4. How He Came to be Known as Vipassī

dn14:1.33.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā nemitte brāhmaṇe ahatehi vatthehi acchādāpetvā sabbakāmehi santappesi.
dn14:1.33.9.eng: Then King Bandhumā had the brahmin soothsayers dressed in unworn clothes and satisfied all their needs.
dn14:1.33.9.comm: This is the dakkhiṇā, the religious offering given in gratitude and respect for the services.

dn14:1.34.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā vipassissa kumārassa dhātiyo upaṭṭhāpesi.
dn14:1.34.1.eng: Then the king appointed nursemaids for Prince Vipassī.
dn14:1.34.1.comm: His birth mother has passed away and there is no mention of a step-mother.

dn14:1.34.2.pli: Aññā khīraṃ pāyenti, aññā nhāpenti, aññā dhārenti, aññā aṅkena pariharanti.
dn14:1.34.2.eng: Some suckled him, some bathed him, some held him, and some carried him on their hip.

dn14:1.34.3.pli: Jātassa kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa setacchattaṃ dhārayittha divā ceva rattiñca:
dn14:1.34.3.eng: From when he was born, a white parasol was held over him night and day, with the thought,

dn14:1.34.4.pli: ‘mā naṃ sītaṃ vā uṇhaṃ vā tiṇaṃ vā rajo vā ussāvo vā bādhayitthā’ti.
dn14:1.34.4.eng: ‘Don’t let cold, heat, grass, dust, or damp bother him.’

dn14:1.34.5.pli: Jāto kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bahuno janassa piyo ahosi manāpo.
dn14:1.34.5.eng: He was dear and beloved by many people,

dn14:1.34.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uppalaṃ vā padumaṃ vā puṇḍarīkaṃ vā bahuno janassa piyaṃ manāpaṃ;
dn14:1.34.6.eng: like a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus.

dn14:1.34.7.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bahuno janassa piyo ahosi manāpo.

dn14:1.34.8.eng: He was always passed from hip to hip.

dn14:1.35.1.pli: Jāto kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro mañjussaro ca ahosi vaggussaro ca madhurassaro ca pemaniyassaro ca.
dn14:1.35.1.eng: From when he was born, his voice was charming, graceful, sweet, and lovely.

dn14:1.35.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, himavante pabbate karavīkā nāma sakuṇajāti mañjussarā ca vaggussarā ca madhurassarā ca pemaniyassarā ca;
dn14:1.35.2.eng: It was as sweet as the song of a cuckoo-bird found in the Himalayas.

dn14:1.35.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro mañjussaro ca ahosi vaggussaro ca madhurassaro ca pemaniyassaro ca.

dn14:1.36.1.pli: Jātassa kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa kammavipākajaṃ dibbacakkhu pāturahosi yena sudaṃ samantā yojanaṃ passati divā ceva rattiñca.
dn14:1.36.1.eng: From when he was born, Prince Vipassī had the power of clairvoyance which manifested as a result of past deeds, by which he could see for a league all around both by day and by night.
dn14:1.36.1.comm: Normally clairvoyance and related abilities are said to arise due to the power of the fourth jhāna, whereas here it comes naturally due to past kamma. After jhāna this ability is empowered by the radiant mind clear of hindrances, whereas here it seems to be a more limited ability to see clearly and in the dark.

dn14:1.37.1.pli: Jāto kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro animisanto pekkhati seyyathāpi devā tāvatiṃsā.
dn14:1.37.1.eng: And he was unblinkingly watchful, like the gods of the thirty-three.

dn14:1.37.2.pli: ‘Animisanto kumāro pekkhatī’ti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa ‘vipassī vipassī’ tveva samaññā udapādi.
dn14:1.37.2.eng: And because it was said that he was unblinkingly watchful, he came to be known as ‘Vipassī’.
dn14:1.37.2.comm: Vipassī’s name is simply the personal form of the word made famous in Buddhist meditation, vipassanā. This is usually rendered as “insight”, but the sense here is more like “clear seeing”.

dn14:1.37.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā atthakaraṇe nisinno vipassiṃ kumāraṃ aṅke nisīdāpetvā atthe anusāsati.
dn14:1.37.3.eng: Then while King Bandhumā was sitting in court, he’d sit Prince Vipassī in his lap and explain the case to him.

dn14:1.37.4.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro pituaṅke nisinno viceyya viceyya atthe panāyati ñāyena.
dn14:1.37.4.eng: And sitting there in his father’s lap, Vipassī would thoroughly consider the case and draw a conclusion using a logical system.

dn14:1.37.5.pli: Viceyya viceyya kumāro atthe panāyati ñāyenāti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa bhiyyoso mattāya ‘vipassī vipassī’ tveva samaññā udapādi.
dn14:1.37.5.eng: So this was all the more reason for him to be known as ‘Vipassī’.
dn14:1.37.5.comm: Indian epistemology acknowledges two fundamental sources of knowledge: direct perception (paccakkha) and inference (anumāna). This passage shows that vipassanā includes both. I render vipassanā with “discernment” in an attempt to capture both nuances, rather than the standard “insight”.

dn14:1.38.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā vipassissa kumārassa tayo pāsāde kārāpesi, ekaṃ vassikaṃ ekaṃ hemantikaṃ ekaṃ gimhikaṃ;
dn14:1.38.1.eng: Then King Bandhumā had three stilt longhouses built for him—one for the winter, one for the summer, and one for the rainy season,

dn14:1.38.2.eng: and provided him with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

dn14:1.38.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro vassike pāsāde cattāro māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamāno na heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ orohatīti.
dn14:1.38.3.eng: Prince Vipassī stayed in a stilt longhouse without coming downstairs for the four months of the rainy season, where he was entertained by musicians—none of them men.

dn14:2.1.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bahūnaṃ vassānaṃ bahūnaṃ vassasatānaṃ bahūnaṃ vassasahassānaṃ accayena sārathiṃ āmantesi:
dn14:2.1.1.eng: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, Prince Vipassī addressed his charioteer,
dn14:2.1.1.comm: Here begins the story of the four signs that led to Vipassī’s going forth—an old man, a sick man, a dead man, and a renunciate. Later texts apply the same story to Siddhattha, indeed to all bodhisattvas. | These four “signs” (nimitta) are also called “messengers of the gods”, reckoned as five (MN 130) or three (AN 3.36).

dn14:2.1.2.pli: ‘yojehi, samma sārathi, bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni uyyānabhūmiṃ gacchāma subhūmidassanāyā’ti.
dn14:2.1.2.eng: ‘My dear charioteer, harness the finest chariots. We will go to a park and see the scenery.’

dn14:2.1.3.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, sārathi vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni yojetvā vipassissa kumārassa paṭivedesi:
dn14:2.1.3.eng: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied the charioteer. He harnessed the chariots and informed the prince,

dn14:2.1.4.pli: ‘yuttāni kho te, deva, bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni,

dn14:2.1.6.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bhaddaṃ bhaddaṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhaddehi bhaddehi yānehi uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyāsi.
dn14:2.1.6.eng: Then Prince Vipassī mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out for the park.

dn14:2.2.1.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyanto purisaṃ jiṇṇaṃ gopānasivaṅkaṃ bhoggaṃ daṇḍaparāyanaṃ pavedhamānaṃ gacchantaṃ āturaṃ gatayobbanaṃ.
dn14:2.2.1.eng: Along the way he saw an elderly man, bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as he walked, ailing, past his prime.

dn14:2.2.3.eng: ‘My dear charioteer, what has that man done?

dn14:2.2.4.pli: Kesāpissa na yathā aññesaṃ, kāyopissa na yathā aññesan’ti.
dn14:2.2.4.eng: For his hair and his body are unlike those of other men.’

dn14:2.2.5.eng: ‘That, Your Majesty, is called an old man.’

dn14:2.2.6.eng: ‘But why is he called an old man?’

dn14:2.2.7.pli: ‘Eso kho, deva, jiṇṇo nāma. Na dāni tena ciraṃ jīvitabbaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
dn14:2.2.7.eng: ‘He’s called an old man because now he has not long to live.’

dn14:2.2.8.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, samma sārathi, ahampi jarādhammo, jaraṃ anatīto’ti?
dn14:2.2.8.eng: ‘But my dear charioteer, am I liable to grow old? Am I not exempt from old age?’

dn14:2.2.9.pli: ‘Tvañca, deva, mayañcamha sabbe jarādhammā, jaraṃ anatītā’ti.
dn14:2.2.9.eng: ‘Everyone is liable to grow old, Your Majesty, including you. No-one is exempt from old age.’

dn14:2.2.10.pli: ‘Tena hi, samma sārathi, alaṃ dānajja uyyānabhūmiyā. Itova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāhī’ti.
dn14:2.2.10.eng: ‘Well then, my dear charioteer, that’s enough of the park for today. Let’s return to the royal compound.’
dn14:2.2.10.comm: Antepuraṁ (“royal compound”) was the inner sanctum of the royal residence. Maximally it referred to the area enclosed by walls within which the ruling families and staff lived. It later became used in the more restricted sense of “harem”.

dn14:2.2.11.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, sārathi vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā tatova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāsi.
dn14:2.2.11.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the charioteer and did so.

dn14:2.2.12.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro antepuraṃ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati:
dn14:2.2.12.eng: Back at the royal compound, the prince brooded, miserable and sad:
dn14:2.2.12.comm: “Brood” is pajjhāyati. He is having an existential crisis.

dn14:2.2.13.pli: ‘dhiratthu kira, bho, jāti nāma, yatra hi nāma jātassa jarā paññāyissatī’ti.
dn14:2.2.13.eng: ‘Curse this thing called rebirth, since old age will come to anyone who’s born.’

dn14:2.3.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā sārathiṃ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
dn14:2.3.1.eng: Then King Bandhumā summoned the charioteer and said,

dn14:2.3.2.pli: ‘kacci, samma sārathi, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā abhiramittha? Kacci, samma sārathi, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā attamano ahosī’ti?
dn14:2.3.2.eng: ‘My dear charioteer, I hope the prince enjoyed himself at the park? I hope he was happy there?’

dn14:2.3.3.pli: ‘Na kho, deva, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā abhiramittha, na kho, deva, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā attamano ahosī’ti.
dn14:2.3.3.eng: ‘No, Your Majesty, the prince didn’t enjoy himself at the park.’

dn14:2.3.4.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, samma sārathi, addasa kumāro uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyanto’ti?
dn14:2.3.4.eng: ‘But what did he see on the way to the park?’

dn14:2.3.5.pli: ‘Addasā kho, deva, kumāro uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyanto purisaṃ jiṇṇaṃ gopānasivaṅkaṃ bhoggaṃ daṇḍaparāyanaṃ pavedhamānaṃ gacchantaṃ āturaṃ gatayobbanaṃ.
dn14:2.3.5.eng: And the charioteer told the king about seeing the old man and the prince’s reaction.

dn14:2.3.7.pli: “ayaṃ pana, samma sārathi, puriso kiṅkato, kesāpissa na yathā aññesaṃ, kāyopissa na yathā aññesan”ti?

dn14:2.3.10.pli: “Eso kho, deva, jiṇṇo nāma na dāni tena ciraṃ jīvitabbaṃ bhavissatī”ti.

dn14:2.3.11.pli: “Kiṃ pana, samma sārathi, ahampi jarādhammo, jaraṃ anatīto”ti?

dn14:2.3.12.pli: “Tvañca, deva, mayañcamha sabbe jarādhammā, jaraṃ anatītā”ti.

dn14:2.3.13.pli: “Tena hi, samma sārathi, alaṃ dānajja uyyānabhūmiyā, itova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāhī”ti.

dn14:2.3.14.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho ahaṃ, deva, vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā tatova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāsiṃ.

dn14:2.3.15.pli: So kho, deva, kumāro antepuraṃ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati:

dn14:2.4.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumassa rañño etadahosi:

dn14:2.4.2.pli: ‘Mā heva kho vipassī kumāro na rajjaṃ kāresi, mā heva vipassī kumāro agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbaji, mā heva nemittānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ assa vacanan’ti.
dn14:2.4.2.eng: ‘Prince Vipassī must not renounce the throne. He must not go forth from the lay life to homelessness. And the words of the brahmin soothsayers must not come true.’
dn14:2.4.2.comm: In any story of prophecy, efforts are made to avert it and they invariably fail. This is a recursive property of prophetic myth. If the prophecy were averted, the myth would not exist and we would not know of it; but because the myth does exist, we know how it ends and the prophecy must come true.

dn14:2.5.1.comm: An existential crisis takes its own time; it cannot be rushed.

dn14:2.6.1.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyanto purisaṃ ābādhikaṃ dukkhitaṃ bāḷhagilānaṃ sake muttakarīse palipannaṃ semānaṃ aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṃ aññehi saṃvesiyamānaṃ.
dn14:2.6.1.eng: Along the way he saw a man who was sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in his own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others.

dn14:2.6.3.eng: ‘My dear charioteer, what has that man done?

dn14:2.6.5.eng: ‘That, Your Majesty, is called a sick man.’

dn14:2.6.6.eng: ‘But why is he called a sick man?’

dn14:2.6.7.pli: ‘Eso kho, deva, byādhito nāma appeva nāma tamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhaheyyā’ti.
dn14:2.6.7.eng: ‘He’s called a sick man; hopefully he will recover from that illness.’

dn14:2.6.8.pli: ‘Kiṃ pana, samma sārathi, ahampi byādhidhammo, byādhiṃ anatīto’ti?
dn14:2.6.8.eng: ‘But my dear charioteer, am I liable to fall sick? Am I not exempt from sickness?’

dn14:2.6.9.pli: ‘Tvañca, deva, mayañcamha sabbe byādhidhammā, byādhiṃ anatītā’ti.
dn14:2.6.9.eng: ‘Everyone is liable to fall sick, Your Majesty, including you. No-one is exempt from sickness.’

dn14:2.6.10.pli: ‘Tena hi, samma sārathi, alaṃ dānajja uyyānabhūmiyā, itova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāhī’ti.
dn14:2.6.10.eng: ‘Well then, my dear charioteer, that’s enough of the park for today. Let’s return to the royal compound.’

dn14:2.6.11.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, sārathi vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā tatova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāsi.
dn14:2.6.11.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the charioteer and did so.

dn14:2.6.13.pli: ‘dhiratthu kira, bho, jāti nāma, yatra hi nāma jātassa jarā paññāyissati, byādhi paññāyissatī’ti.
dn14:2.6.13.eng: ‘Curse this thing called rebirth, since old age and sickness will come to anyone who’s born.’

dn14:2.10.3.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho so, samma sārathi, mahājanakāyo sannipatito nānārattānañca dussānaṃ vilātaṃ kayiratī’ti?

dn14:2.10.9.pli: ‘Eso kho, deva, kālaṅkato nāma. Na dāni taṃ dakkhanti mātā vā pitā vā aññe vā ñātisālohitā, sopi na dakkhissati mātaraṃ vā pitaraṃ vā aññe vā ñātisālohite’ti.

dn14:2.10.11.eng: Will the king and queen and my other relatives and kin see me no more?

dn14:2.10.12.pli: ahampi na dakkhissāmi devaṃ vā deviṃ vā aññe vā ñātisālohite’ti?
dn14:2.10.12.eng: And shall I never again see them?’

dn14:2.10.14.eng: The king and queen and your other relatives and kin shall see you no more,

dn14:2.10.15.eng: and you shall never again see them.’

dn14:2.13.5.pli: ‘yuttāni kho te, deva, bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni,

dn14:2.13.7.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bhaddaṃ bhaddaṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhaddehi bhaddehi yānehi uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyāsi.

dn14:2.14.1.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyanto purisaṃ bhaṇḍuṃ pabbajitaṃ kāsāyavasanaṃ.
dn14:2.14.1.eng: Along the way he saw a man, a renunciate with shaven head, wearing an ocher robe.
dn14:2.14.1.comm: “Renunciate” is pabbajita (“one who has gone forth”), one of the many words for religious ascetics. It is a general term and does not specify his affiliation.

dn14:2.14.3.eng: ‘My dear charioteer, what has that man done?

dn14:2.14.4.pli: Sīsampissa na yathā aññesaṃ, vatthānipissa na yathā aññesan’ti?
dn14:2.14.4.eng: For his head and his clothes are unlike those of other men.’

dn14:2.14.5.eng: ‘That, Your Majesty, is called a renunciate.’

dn14:2.14.6.eng: ‘But why is he called a renunciate?’

dn14:2.14.7.pli: ‘Eso kho, deva, pabbajito nāma sādhu dhammacariyā sādhu samacariyā sādhu kusalakiriyā sādhu puññakiriyā sādhu avihiṃsā sādhu bhūtānukampā’ti.
dn14:2.14.7.eng: ‘He is called a renunciate because he celebrates principled and fair conduct, skillful actions, good deeds, harmlessness, and sympathy for living creatures.’
dn14:2.14.7.comm: “Celebrate” is sādhu, the famous Buddhist words of approval and rejoicing still heard every day in Theravāda Buddhist cultures.
