It later acquired the meaning “renunciate” but does not have that sense in early Pali. The virtues that he celebrates are common values of Indian religions.

dn14:2.14.8.pli: ‘Sādhu kho so, samma sārathi, pabbajito nāma, sādhu dhammacariyā sādhu samacariyā sādhu kusalakiriyā sādhu puññakiriyā sādhu avihiṃsā sādhu bhūtānukampā.
dn14:2.14.8.eng: ‘Then I celebrate the one called a renunciate, who celebrates principled and fair conduct, skillful actions, good deeds, harmlessness, and sympathy for living creatures!

dn14:2.14.9.pli: Tena hi, samma sārathi, yena so pabbajito tena rathaṃ pesehī’ti.
dn14:2.14.9.eng: Well then, drive the chariot up to that renunciate.’

dn14:2.14.10.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, sārathi vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā yena so pabbajito tena rathaṃ pesesi.
dn14:2.14.10.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the charioteer, and did so.

dn14:2.14.11.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro taṃ pabbajitaṃ etadavoca:
dn14:2.14.11.eng: Then Prince Vipassī said to that renunciate,

dn14:2.14.12.eng: ‘My good man, what have you done?

dn14:2.14.13.pli: sīsampi te na yathā aññesaṃ, vatthānipi te na yathā aññesan’ti?
dn14:2.14.13.eng: For your head and your clothes are unlike those of other men.’

dn14:2.14.14.eng: ‘Sire, I am what is called a renunciate.’

dn14:2.14.15.eng: ‘But why are you called a renunciate?’

dn14:2.14.16.pli: ‘Ahaṃ kho, deva, pabbajito nāma, sādhu dhammacariyā sādhu samacariyā sādhu kusalakiriyā sādhu puññakiriyā sādhu avihiṃsā sādhu bhūtānukampā’ti.
dn14:2.14.16.eng: ‘I am called a renunciate because I celebrate principled and fair conduct, skillful actions, good deeds, harmlessness, and sympathy for living creatures.’

dn14:2.14.17.pli: ‘Sādhu kho tvaṃ, samma, pabbajito nāma sādhu dhammacariyā sādhu samacariyā sādhu kusalakiriyā sādhu puññakiriyā sādhu avihiṃsā sādhu bhūtānukampā’ti.
dn14:2.14.17.eng: ‘Then I celebrate the one called a renunciate, who celebrates principled and fair conduct, skillful actions, good deeds, harmlessness, and sympathy for living creatures!’

dn14:2.15.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro sārathiṃ āmantesi:
dn14:2.15.1.eng: Then the prince addressed the charioteer,

dn14:2.15.2.pli: ‘tena hi, samma sārathi, rathaṃ ādāya itova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāhi.
dn14:2.15.2.eng: ‘Well then, my dear charioteer, take the chariot and return to the royal compound.

dn14:2.15.3.pli: Ahaṃ pana idheva kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāmī’ti.
dn14:2.15.3.eng: I shall shave off my hair and beard right here, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
dn14:2.15.3.comm: His apparently sudden decision to go forth arises only after an extensive period of crisis and contemplation.

dn14:2.15.4.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, sārathi vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā rathaṃ ādāya tatova antepuraṃ paccaniyyāsi.
dn14:2.15.4.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the charioteer and did so.

dn14:2.15.5.pli: Vipassī pana kumāro tattheva kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbaji.
dn14:2.15.5.eng: Then Prince Vipassī shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn14:2.16.1.pli: Assosi kho, bhikkhave, bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā mahājanakāyo caturāsītipāṇasahassāni:
dn14:2.16.1.eng: A large crowd of 84,000 people in the capital of Bandhumatī heard

dn14:2.16.2.pli: ‘vipassī kira kumāro kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito’ti.

dn14:2.16.4.pli: ‘na hi nūna so orako dhammavinayo, na sā orakā pabbajjā, yattha vipassī kumāro kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
dn14:2.16.4.eng: ‘This must be no ordinary teaching and training, no ordinary going forth in which Prince Vipassī has gone forth.

dn14:2.16.5.pli: Vipassīpi nāma kumāro kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissati, kimaṅgaṃ pana mayan’ti.
dn14:2.16.5.eng: If even the prince goes forth, why don’t we do the same?’

dn14:2.16.6.pli: Atha kho, so bhikkhave, mahājanakāyo caturāsītipāṇasahassāni kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā vipassiṃ bodhisattaṃ agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitaṃ anupabbajiṃsu.
dn14:2.16.6.eng: Then that great crowd of 84,000 people shaved off their hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and followed the one intent on awakening, Vipassī, by going forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn14:2.16.6.comm: The idea that a whole populace would follow the bodhisatta on his renunciate path occurs several times in the Jātakas.

dn14:2.16.7.pli: Tāya sudaṃ, bhikkhave, parisāya parivuto vipassī bodhisatto gāmanigamajanapadarājadhānīsu cārikaṃ carati.
dn14:2.16.7.eng: Escorted by that assembly, Vipassī wandered on tour among the villages, towns, and capital cities.
dn14:2.16.7.comm: Following the PTS edition in omitting janapada, which is absent from the commentary and the parallel passage at DN 19:58.3.

dn14:2.17.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
dn14:2.17.1.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

dn14:2.17.2.pli: ‘na kho metaṃ patirūpaṃ yohaṃ ākiṇṇo viharāmi, yannūnāhaṃ eko gaṇamhā vūpakaṭṭho vihareyyan’ti.
dn14:2.17.2.eng: ‘It’s not appropriate for me to live in a crowd. Why don’t I live alone, withdrawn from the group?’

dn14:2.17.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bodhisatto aparena samayena eko gaṇamhā vūpakaṭṭho vihāsi, aññeneva tāni caturāsītipabbajitasahassāni agamaṃsu, aññena maggena vipassī bodhisatto.
dn14:2.17.3.eng: After some time he withdrew from the group to live alone. The 84,000 went one way, but Vipassī went another.

dn14:2.18.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa vāsūpagatassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
dn14:2.18.1.eng: Then as Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, was in private retreat in his dwelling, this thought came to his mind,
dn14:2.18.1.comm: This is the only place vāsūpagata (“entered his dwelling”) is added to this stock phrase.

dn14:2.18.2.pli: ‘kicchaṃ vatāyaṃ loko āpanno, jāyati ca jīyati ca mīyati ca cavati ca upapajjati ca, atha ca panimassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṃ nappajānāti jarāmaraṇassa,
dn14:2.18.2.eng: ‘Alas, this world has fallen into trouble. It’s born, grows old, dies, passes away, and is reborn, yet it doesn’t understand how to escape from this suffering, from old age and death.
dn14:2.18.2.comm: At SN 12.4–10 this same reflection is attributed to each of the seven past Buddhas, kicking off an investigation into dependent origination in reverse order, starting with the outcome: suffering. Here this is treated as a meditative contemplation, whereas the next sutta, DN 15 Mahānidānasutta, delves into the philosophical implications.

dn14:2.18.3.pli: kudāssu nāma imassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāyissati jarāmaraṇassā’ti?
dn14:2.18.3.eng: Oh, when will an escape be found from this suffering, from old age and death?’

dn14:2.18.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.5.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, kiṃpaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti?
dn14:2.18.5.eng: ‘When what exists is there old age and death? What is a requirement for old age and death?’
dn14:2.18.5.comm: The reflection shows how the bodhisatta is still digging into the trauma of discovering the reality of old age and death.

dn14:2.18.6.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.6.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,
dn14:2.18.6.comm: Yoniso maniskāra (“rational application of mind”) is a distinctively Buddhist term that literally means “applying the mind by way of source”. It is mostly used in investigating causality, although over time it came to have a more general sense of “reflection, inquiry, attention”.

dn14:2.18.7.pli: ‘jātiyā kho sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hoti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti.
dn14:2.18.7.eng: ‘When rebirth exists there’s old age and death. Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death.’
dn14:2.18.7.comm: Here begins the sequence of dependent origination. I give basic definitions of terms here, and more details in DN 15. See also my notes in the Nidānasaṁyutta, especially SN 12.1 and SN 12.2. | Rebirth is a necessary antecedent condition for old age and death. Note that it is not a sufficient condition for old age, for many die when young.

dn14:2.18.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.9.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati jāti hoti, kiṃpaccayā jātī’ti?
dn14:2.18.9.eng: ‘When what exists is there rebirth? What is a requirement for rebirth?’
dn14:2.18.9.comm: Since there cannot be an end to the “birth” that starts this life, jāti means “rebirth”, the next stage in the ongoing cycle.

dn14:2.18.10.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.10.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.11.pli: ‘bhave kho sati jāti hoti, bhavapaccayā jātī’ti.
dn14:2.18.11.eng: ‘When continued existence exists there’s rebirth. Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.’
dn14:2.18.11.comm: Bhava means “being, existence, life” in the sense of “past and future lives”. It refers to the ongoing process of continued existence, transmigrating through life after life. By itself, bhava has a positive connotation, and represents the longing that many people have to continue to exist after death in a permanent and happy state. The Buddha, however, situates it as just one more dimension of the flow of conditions.

dn14:2.18.12.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.13.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati bhavo hoti, kiṃpaccayā bhavo’ti?
dn14:2.18.13.eng: ‘When what exists is there continued existence? What is a requirement for continued existence?’

dn14:2.18.14.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.14.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.15.pli: ‘upādāne kho sati bhavo hoti, upādānapaccayā bhavo’ti.
dn14:2.18.15.eng: ‘When grasping exists there’s continued existence. Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.’
dn14:2.18.15.comm: “Grasping” (upādāna) at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self (DN 15:6.3). Grasping has the active sense of “taking up” a new life, not just “clinging” to what one has. It has a dual sense, because it also means the “fuel” that sustains the fire of existence.

dn14:2.18.16.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.17.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati upādānaṃ hoti, kiṃpaccayā upādānan’ti?
dn14:2.18.17.eng: ‘When what exists is there grasping? What is a requirement for grasping?’

dn14:2.18.18.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.18.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.19.pli: ‘taṇhāya kho sati upādānaṃ hoti, taṇhāpaccayā upādānan’ti.
dn14:2.18.19.eng: ‘When craving exists there’s grasping. Craving is a requirement for grasping.’
dn14:2.18.19.comm: Craving (taṇhā, literally “thirst”) and grasping have a similar meaning, but craving is primal desire while grasping is more complex, involving doctrines and behaviors.

dn14:2.18.20.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.21.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati taṇhā hoti, kiṃpaccayā taṇhā’ti?
dn14:2.18.21.eng: ‘When what exists is there craving? What is a requirement for craving?’

dn14:2.18.22.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.22.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.23.pli: ‘vedanāya kho sati taṇhā hoti, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā’ti.
dn14:2.18.23.eng: ‘When feeling exists there’s craving. Feeling is a requirement for craving.’
dn14:2.18.23.comm: “Feeling” (vedanā) is more fundamental than the complex concept of “emotion”. It refers to the hedonic tone of experience as pleasant, painful, or neutral.

dn14:2.18.24.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.25.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati vedanā hoti, kiṃpaccayā vedanā’ti?
dn14:2.18.25.eng: ‘When what exists is there feeling? What is a requirement for feeling?’

dn14:2.18.26.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.26.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.27.pli: ‘phasse kho sati vedanā hoti, phassapaccayā vedanā’ti.
dn14:2.18.27.eng: ‘When contact exists there’s feeling. Contact is a requirement for feeling.’
dn14:2.18.27.comm: “Contact” is literally “touch” (phassa), and refers to the stimulation that occurs when sense object meets sense organ in experience.

dn14:2.18.28.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.29.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati phasso hoti, kiṃpaccayā phasso’ti?
dn14:2.18.29.eng: ‘When what exists is there contact? What is a requirement for contact?’

dn14:2.18.30.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.30.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.31.pli: ‘saḷāyatane kho sati phasso hoti, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso’ti.
dn14:2.18.31.eng: ‘When the six sense fields exist there’s contact. The six sense fields are requirements for contact.’
dn14:2.18.31.comm: The five senses with the mind as sixth. This topic is treated extensively throughout early Buddhism, with a special focus on understanding and restraining the pull of sense stimulation. Āyatana has a root sense “stretch”, from which derived senses include “dimension”, “field”, etc.

dn14:2.18.32.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.33.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati saḷāyatanaṃ hoti, kiṃpaccayā saḷāyatanan’ti?
dn14:2.18.33.eng: ‘When what exists are there the six sense fields? What is a requirement for the six sense fields?’

dn14:2.18.34.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.34.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.35.pli: ‘nāmarūpe kho sati saḷāyatanaṃ hoti, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanan’ti.
dn14:2.18.35.eng: ‘When name and form exist there are the six sense fields. Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.’
dn14:2.18.35.comm: “Name and form” (nāmarūpa) is a Vedic concept referring to the multiplicity of material forms (rūpa) and associated names (nāma), especially the individual “sentient organisms” such as gods and humans (Rig Veda 5.43.10, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.6.1, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.2), which are ultimately absorbed into the divine, like rivers in the ocean (Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 3.2.8, Praśna Upaniṣad 6.5). The Buddha treated “name” analytically as feeling, perception, intention, contact, and application of mind, and “form” as the four elements and derived matter (DN 15:20.8, MN 9:52–54.7, and SN 12.2:11.1).

dn14:2.18.36.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.37.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati nāmarūpaṃ hoti, kiṃpaccayā nāmarūpan’ti?
dn14:2.18.37.eng: ‘When what exists are there name and form? What is a requirement for name and form?’

dn14:2.18.38.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.38.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.39.pli: ‘viññāṇe kho sati nāmarūpaṃ hoti, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpan’ti.
dn14:2.18.39.eng: ‘When consciousness exists there are name and form. Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.’
dn14:2.18.39.comm: “Consciousness” (viññāṇa) is simple subjective awareness, the sense of knowing. It arises stimulated by either an external sense impression or a mental phenomena such as thought, memory, etc. It is the subjective awareness that makes the entire multiform world of concepts and appearances possible. Thus far the analysis agrees with Yājñavalkya, who says that the manifold appearances in the world arise from consciousness (etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12).

dn14:2.18.40.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.18.41.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho sati viññāṇaṃ hoti, kiṃpaccayā viññāṇan’ti?
dn14:2.18.41.eng: ‘When what exists is there consciousness? What is a requirement for consciousness?’

dn14:2.18.42.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.18.42.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.18.43.pli: ‘nāmarūpe kho sati viññāṇaṃ hoti, nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇan’ti.
dn14:2.18.43.eng: ‘When name and form exist there’s consciousness. Name and form are requirements for consciousness.’
dn14:2.18.43.comm: Here the Buddha decisively departs from Yājñavalkya’s view that individuated awareness (saññā) returns into “this great reality, infinite, unbounded, a sheer mass of consciousness” (idaṁ mahadbhūtam anantam apāraṁ vijñānaghana eva, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12). Consciousness (viññāṇa) is not a fundamental reality (mahadbhūta) underlying multiplicity, but rather a conditioned process that exists only together with name and form.

dn14:2.19.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.19.2.pli: ‘paccudāvattati kho idaṃ viññāṇaṃ nāmarūpamhā, nāparaṃ gacchati.
dn14:2.19.2.eng: ‘This consciousness turns back from name and form, and doesn’t go beyond that.’
dn14:2.19.2.comm: Dependent origination normally continues with two further factors: choices and ignorance. The full series does not appear in the Dīghanikāya. This truncated series emphasizes the mutuality of name and form with consciousness, but does not preclude the normal linear series. Each presentation of dependent origination reveals a different aspect of a complex, ramified process.

dn14:2.19.3.pli: Ettāvatā jāyetha vā jiyyetha vā miyyetha vā cavetha vā upapajjetha vā, yadidaṃ
dn14:2.19.3.eng: This is the extent to which one may be reborn, grow old, die, pass away, or reappear. That is:

dn14:2.19.4.pli: nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṃ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
dn14:2.19.4.eng: Name and form are requirements for consciousness. Consciousness is a requirement for name and form. Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields. The six sense fields are requirements for contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling. Feeling is a requirement for craving. Craving is a requirement for grasping. Grasping is a requirement for continued existence. Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth. Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
dn14:2.19.4.comm: Note the use of repetition to sum up the main doctrinal teachings. This serves to lock the sequence in memory and ensure no items are missing or displaced, while for one who is reciting the text from memory it provides an opportunity to reflect and apply the meaning in their own experience.

dn14:2.19.5.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’

dn14:2.19.6.pli: ‘Samudayo samudayo’ti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
dn14:2.19.6.eng: ‘Origination, origination.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, regarding teachings not learned before from another.
dn14:2.19.6.comm: This phrasing recalls the Buddha’s first sermon (SN 56.11:5.1), an insight that is said to be common to all Buddhas (SN 56.12:1.1). Pubbe ananussutesu (“not learned before from another”) means that this is a fresh insight not passed down in an oral tradition.

dn14:2.20.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.2.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na hoti, kissa nirodhā jarāmaraṇanirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.2.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no old age and death? When what ceases do old age and death cease?’

dn14:2.20.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.3.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.4.pli: ‘jātiyā kho asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na hoti, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇanirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.4.eng: ‘When rebirth doesn’t exist there’s no old age and death. When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.’

dn14:2.20.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.6.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati jāti na hoti, kissa nirodhā jātinirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.6.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no rebirth? When what ceases does rebirth cease?’

dn14:2.20.7.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.7.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.8.pli: ‘bhave kho asati jāti na hoti, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.8.eng: ‘When continued existence doesn’t exist there’s no rebirth. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.’

dn14:2.20.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.10.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati bhavo na hoti, kissa nirodhā bhavanirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.10.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no continued existence? When what ceases does continued existence cease?’

dn14:2.20.11.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.11.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.12.pli: ‘upādāne kho asati bhavo na hoti, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.12.eng: ‘When grasping doesn’t exist there’s no continued existence. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.’

dn14:2.20.13.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.14.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati upādānaṃ na hoti, kissa nirodhā upādānanirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.14.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no grasping? When what ceases does grasping cease?’

dn14:2.20.15.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.15.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.16.pli: ‘taṇhāya kho asati upādānaṃ na hoti, taṇhānirodhā upādānanirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.16.eng: ‘When craving doesn’t exist there’s no grasping. When craving ceases, grasping ceases.’

dn14:2.20.17.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.18.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati taṇhā na hoti, kissa nirodhā taṇhānirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.18.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no craving? When what ceases does craving cease?’

dn14:2.20.19.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.19.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.20.pli: ‘vedanāya kho asati taṇhā na hoti, vedanānirodhā taṇhānirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.20.eng: ‘When feeling doesn’t exist there’s no craving. When feeling ceases, craving ceases.’

dn14:2.20.21.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.22.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati vedanā na hoti, kissa nirodhā vedanānirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.22.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no feeling? When what ceases does feeling cease?’

dn14:2.20.23.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.23.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.24.pli: ‘phasse kho asati vedanā na hoti, phassanirodhā vedanānirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.24.eng: ‘When contact doesn’t exist there’s no feeling. When contact ceases, feeling ceases.’

dn14:2.20.25.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.26.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati phasso na hoti, kissa nirodhā phassanirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.26.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no contact? When what ceases does contact cease?’

dn14:2.20.27.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.27.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.28.pli: ‘saḷāyatane kho asati phasso na hoti, saḷāyatananirodhā phassanirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.28.eng: ‘When the six sense fields don’t exist there’s no contact. When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.’

dn14:2.20.29.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.30.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati saḷāyatanaṃ na hoti, kissa nirodhā saḷāyatananirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.30.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist are there no six sense fields? When what ceases do the six sense fields cease?’

dn14:2.20.31.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.31.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.32.pli: ‘nāmarūpe kho asati saḷāyatanaṃ na hoti, nāmarūpanirodhā saḷāyatananirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.32.eng: ‘When name and form don’t exist there are no six sense fields. When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.’

dn14:2.20.33.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.34.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati nāmarūpaṃ na hoti, kissa nirodhā nāmarūpanirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.34.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist are there no name and form? When what ceases do name and form cease?’

dn14:2.20.35.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.35.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.36.pli: ‘viññāṇe kho asati nāmarūpaṃ na hoti, viññāṇanirodhā nāmarūpanirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.36.eng: ‘When consciousness doesn’t exist there are no name and form. When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.’

dn14:2.20.37.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.20.38.pli: ‘kimhi nu kho asati viññāṇaṃ na hoti, kissa nirodhā viññāṇanirodho’ti?
dn14:2.20.38.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no consciousness? When what ceases does consciousness cease?’

dn14:2.20.39.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāya abhisamayo:
dn14:2.20.39.eng: Then, through rational application of mind, Vipassī penetrated with wisdom,

dn14:2.20.40.pli: ‘nāmarūpe kho asati viññāṇaṃ na hoti, nāmarūpanirodhā viññāṇanirodho’ti.
dn14:2.20.40.eng: ‘When name and form don’t exist there’s no consciousness. When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.’

dn14:2.21.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa etadahosi:

dn14:2.21.2.eng: ‘I have discovered the path to awakening. That is:
dn14:2.21.2.comm: The PTS edition has vipassanā-maggo here, despite admitting the term is found in no manuscripts and is taken from the commentary, where it is clearly an explanation not a reading (maggoti vipassanāmaggo). This error is followed by Rhys Davids and Walshe in their translations.

dn14:2.21.3.pli: nāmarūpanirodhā viññāṇanirodho, viññāṇanirodhā nāmarūpanirodho, nāmarūpanirodhā saḷāyatananirodho, saḷāyatananirodhā phassanirodho, phassanirodhā vedanānirodho, vedanānirodhā taṇhānirodho, taṇhānirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti.
dn14:2.21.3.eng: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases. When consciousness ceases, name and form cease. When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. When contact ceases, feeling ceases. When feeling ceases, craving ceases. When craving ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

dn14:2.21.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’

dn14:2.21.5.pli: ‘Nirodho nirodho’ti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bodhisattassa pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
dn14:2.21.5.eng: ‘Cessation, cessation.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, regarding teachings not learned before from another.
dn14:2.21.5.comm: Insight into dependent origination here indicates the attaining of stream entry.

dn14:2.22.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bodhisatto aparena samayena pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassī vihāsi:
dn14:2.22.1.eng: After some time he meditated observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.
dn14:2.22.1.comm: The five grasping aggregates (pañcūpādānakkhandhā) are mentioned as a summary of suffering in the Buddha’s first sermon (SN 56.11:4.2). Most of the teachings on this topic are collected in the Khandhasaṁyutta at SN 22, but they are also found in the Dīghanikāya at DN 22:14.1, DN 33:1.11.45, DN 33:2.1.4, and DN 34:1.6.16. The contemplation on the aggregates dispels the mistaken assumption of a self. Many of the theorists in DN 1 identify the self with one or other of the aggregates.

dn14:2.22.2.pli: ‘iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
dn14:2.22.2.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

dn14:2.22.3.pli: iti vedanā, iti vedanāya samudayo, iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
dn14:2.22.3.eng: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.

dn14:2.22.4.pli: iti saññā, iti saññāya samudayo, iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
dn14:2.22.4.eng: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.

dn14:2.22.5.pli: iti saṅkhārā, iti saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo, iti saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo;
dn14:2.22.5.eng: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
dn14:2.22.5.comm: Saṅkhāra in early Buddhism has three main doctrinal senses. (1) The broadest sense is “conditioned phenomena”, which we find in the Dīghanikāya at DN 16:6.10.10, DN 17:2.16.1, and DN 34:1.8.59. This essentially means “everything except Nibbana”. (2) Sometimes it is a physical or mental “process” or “activity” as at DN 18:24.1, where it refers to the gradual stilling of energies in the development of meditation. (3) In the five aggregates and dependent origination it has the sense of “morally potent volitions or choices” and is a synonym for cetanā (“intention”). It is defined as good, bad, and imperturbable choices (DN 33:1.10.77), the latter of which refers to the kamma of the fourth jhāna and above. In this sense it is the moral “choices” for good or ill that propel consciousness into a new rebirth.

dn14:2.22.6.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti,
dn14:2.22.6.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
dn14:2.22.6.comm: The radical thesis of the Buddha’s teaching is the idea that consciousness is merely another empirical phenomena that comes to an end, as is also emphasized in the concluding verses of DN 11.

dn14:2.22.7.pli: tassa pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino viharato na cirasseva anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccīti.
dn14:2.22.7.eng: Meditating like this his mind was soon freed from defilements by not grasping.
dn14:2.22.7.comm: This indicates the attainment of arahantship, the complete release from all attachments leading to rebirth.

dn14:3.1.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa etadahosi:
dn14:3.1.1.eng: Then it occurred to the Blessed One Vipassī, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha,
dn14:3.1.1.comm: No longer a bodhisatta, he is now called a Buddha for the first time.

dn14:3.1.2.comm: In early Buddhism, the idea of teaching the Dhamma only arose after awakening.

dn14:3.1.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa etadahosi:

dn14:3.1.4.pli: ‘adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.
dn14:3.1.4.eng: ‘This principle I have discovered is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
dn14:3.1.4.comm: A similar account is told of Gotama Buddha at SN 6.1:1.4, MN 26:19.2, MN 85:43.2, and Kd 1:5.2.2.

dn14:3.1.5.pli: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṃ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.
dn14:3.1.5.eng: But people like clinging, they love it and enjoy it.
dn14:3.1.5.comm: Here “clinging” is ālaya, from a root meaning “to stick”.

dn14:3.1.6.pli: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṃ idaṃ ṭhānaṃ yadidaṃ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo.
dn14:3.1.6.eng: It’s hard for them to see this topic; that is, specific conditionality, dependent origination.
dn14:3.1.6.comm: “Specific conditionality” ( idappaccayatā) refers to the fact that dependent origination traces the specific conditions for other specific things: this conditions that. It is not a general principle of universal conditionality (“everything is interconnected”).

dn14:3.1.7.pli: Idampi kho ṭhānaṃ duddasaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
dn14:3.1.7.eng: It’s also hard for them to see this topic; that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
dn14:3.1.7.comm: “Stilling of all activities” (sabbasaṅkhārasamatho) is the cessation of all conditioned energies or phenomena. | “Attachment” here is upadhi, which is both the things of the world to which we cling, and the inner clinging. The Jains defined upadhi similarly (Tattvārthasūtra 9.26). The dominant meaning in Sanskrit is “fraud”, which perhaps informs the Buddhist sense.

dn14:3.1.8.pli: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, pare ca me na ājāneyyuṃ; so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā’ti.
dn14:3.1.8.eng: And if I were to teach this principle, others might not understand me, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.’
dn14:3.1.8.comm: The commentary is careful to specify that the Buddha means physical exhaustion only.

dn14:3.2.1.pli: Apissu, bhikkhave, vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsu pubbe assutapubbā:
dn14:3.2.1.eng: And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to him:
dn14:3.2.1.comm: “Not supernaturally inspired” (anacchariyā) rejects the Vedic “channeling” of scripture from the Divinity, while “not learned before in the past” (pubbe assutapubbā), echoing the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11:5.1), rejects the oral tradition.

dn14:3.2.3.eng: enough with trying to explain it!

dn14:3.2.4.eng: Those mired in greed and hate

dn14:3.2.6.eng: It goes against the stream, subtle,

dn14:3.2.8.eng: Those besotted by greed cannot see,

dn14:3.2.9.eng: for they’re shrouded in a mass of darkness.’
dn14:3.2.9.comm: “Shrouded” is āvuṭā, which is from the same root as asaṁvutā in DN 14:1.17.5 above, as well as nīvaraṇa (“hindrance”). All these terms ultimately stem from the Vedic serpent Vṛtra (“the constrictor”) who wraps the world in darkness.

dn14:3.2.10.pli: Itiha, bhikkhave, vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭisañcikkhato appossukkatāya cittaṃ nami, no dhammadesanāya.
dn14:3.2.10.eng: So, as the Buddha Vipassī reflected like this, his mind inclined to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.
dn14:3.2.10.comm: Had he followed this inclination he would have been a paccekabuddha, a Buddha “awakened for himself”.

dn14:3.2.11.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññatarassa mahābrahmuno vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya etadahosi:
dn14:3.2.11.eng: Then, knowing the Buddha Vipassī’s train of thought, it occurred to a certain Great Divinity,
dn14:3.2.11.comm: In the accounts of Gotama’s life this is specified as Brahmā Sahampati (see MN 26:20.1 and note). This whole passage is a moment of high cosmic solemnity and drama.

dn14:3.2.12.pli: ‘nassati vata bho loko, vinassati vata bho loko, yatra hi nāma vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāyā’ti.
dn14:3.2.12.eng: ‘Oh lord! The world will be lost, the world will perish! For the mind of the Blessed One Vipassī, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, inclines to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.’

dn14:3.2.13.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mahābrahmā seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa purato pāturahosi.
dn14:3.2.13.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha Vipassī.

dn14:3.3.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mahābrahmā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā dakkhiṇaṃ jāṇumaṇḍalaṃ pathaviyaṃ nihantvā yena vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
dn14:3.3.1.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha Vipassī, and said,

dn14:3.3.2.pli: ‘desetu, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ,
dn14:3.3.2.eng: ‘Sir, let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach the Dhamma!
dn14:3.3.2.comm: The Buddha teaches on the invitation of the highest divinity. This sets a precedent for Buddhists to refrain from proselytizing, but rather teach by invitation. These passages are still recited in some places to invite a teaching.

dn14:3.3.3.pli: santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā; assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti,
dn14:3.3.3.eng: There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.

dn14:3.3.4.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!’
dn14:3.3.4.comm: Aññātāro is an agent noun in plural, literally “understanders”.

dn14:3.4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho taṃ mahābrahmānaṃ etadavoca:
dn14:3.4.1.eng: When he said this, the Buddha Vipassī said to him,

dn14:3.4.5.pli: “adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.

dn14:3.4.6.pli: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṃ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.

dn14:3.4.7.pli: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṃ idaṃ ṭhānaṃ yadidaṃ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo.

dn14:3.4.8.pli: Idampi kho ṭhānaṃ duddasaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.

dn14:3.4.9.pli: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, pare ca me na ājāneyyuṃ; so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.
dn14:3.4.9.eng: “If I were to teach this principle, others might not understand me, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”

dn14:3.4.10.pli: Apissu maṃ, brahme, imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsu pubbe assutapubbā:

dn14:3.4.19.pli: Itiha me, brahme, paṭisañcikkhato appossukkatāya cittaṃ nami, no dhammadesanāyā’ti.
dn14:3.4.19.eng: So, as I reflected like this, my mind inclined to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.’

dn14:3.5.2.pli: tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, so mahābrahmā vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
dn14:3.5.2.eng: and a third time that Great Divinity begged the Buddha to teach.

dn14:3.5.3.pli: ‘desetu, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ, santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, bhavissanti dhammassa aññātāro’ti.

dn14:3.6.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho brahmuno ca ajjhesanaṃ viditvā sattesu ca kāruññataṃ paṭicca buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesi.
dn14:3.6.1.eng: Then, understanding the Divinity’s invitation, the Buddha Vipassī surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha, out of his compassion for sentient beings.
dn14:3.6.1.comm: Previously he simply reflected to himself, now he uses his psychic abilities to ascertain people’s spiritual potential.

dn14:3.6.2.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.
dn14:3.6.2.eng: And he saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes; with keen faculties and with weak faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and hard to teach. And some of them lived seeing the danger in the fault to do with the next world, while others did not.
dn14:3.6.2.comm: Indriya (“faculty”) is an abstract noun from indra, the name of the potent Vedic god of war. In the Vedas, Indra manifests his indriya by drinking soma. The drug enables him to release his full potential and power; originally this probably referred to drinking an amphetamine-like substance before battle. Here we see that it means something like “spiritual potential” which is unleashed by the practice of the eightfold path.

dn14:3.6.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni anto nimuggaposīni. Appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni samodakaṃ ṭhitāni. Appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakā accuggamma ṭhitāni anupalittāni udakena.
dn14:3.6.3.eng: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. Some of them sprout and grow in the water reaching the water’s surface. And some of them sprout and grow in the water but rise up above the water and stand with no water clinging to them.

dn14:3.6.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento addasa satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.
dn14:3.6.4.eng: In the same way, the Buddha Vipassī saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes.

dn14:3.7.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mahābrahmā vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
dn14:3.7.1.eng: Then that Great Divinity, knowing the Buddha Vipassī’s train of thought, addressed him in verse:

dn14:3.7.3.eng: you can see the people all around.

dn14:3.7.4.eng: In just the same way, All-seer, so intelligent,

dn14:3.7.5.eng: having ascended the Temple of Truth,

dn14:3.7.6.eng: rid of sorrow, look upon the people

dn14:3.7.7.eng: swamped with sorrow, overcome by rebirth and old age.

dn14:3.7.8.eng: Rise, hero! Victor in battle, caravan leader,
dn14:3.7.8.comm: Here we see a verbal echo of Sahampati’s martial origins.

dn14:3.7.9.eng: wander the world cleared of debt.
dn14:3.7.9.comm: A “caravan leader” (satthavāha) guides their flock through treacherous deserts and wastelands, as illustrated at DN 23:23.3. | Anaṇa (“debtless”) is a technical term in the Vedic system. According to Manu 6.35–7, a renunciate must first pay off three debts: study of Vedas, begetting a son, and offering of sacrifices. One who goes forth with these debts unpaid is headed for a downfall. The Buddha has indeed paid off all these debts: he studied the Vedas under his former teachers (MN 26:15.6); he has a son Rāhula; and his path is regarded as the highest form of sacrifice (DN 5:24.1). But in Buddhism the concept is reinterpreted as meaning one has let go of all defilements, becoming a “perfected”, literally “worthy” one, after which one can eat almsfood free of debt (MN 124:38.1, SN 16.11:13.2).

dn14:3.7.10.eng: Let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma!

dn14:3.7.11.eng: There will be those who understand!’

dn14:3.7.12.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho taṃ mahābrahmānaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
dn14:3.7.12.eng: Then the Buddha Vipassī addressed that Great Divinity in verse:

dn14:3.7.13.eng: ‘Flung open are the doors to freedom from death!

dn14:3.7.14.eng: Let those with ears to hear commit to faith.
dn14:3.7.14.comm: Pamuñcantu saddhaṁ has long troubled translators, as the basic sense of pamuñcantu is “release”. The problem is a long-standing one, for Sanskrit variants include pramodantu (“celebrate”) or praṇudantu kāṅkṣāḥ (“dispel doubts”). I think it is a poetic variant of adhimuñcantu, to “decide” or “commit” to faith. Pali commonly uses a synonymous verb to reinforce the sense of the noun. In Snp 5.19, muttasaddho, pamuñcassu saddhaṁ, and adhimuttacittaṁ are all used in this sense.

dn14:3.7.15.eng: Thinking it would be troublesome, Divinity, <j>I did not teach

dn14:3.7.16.eng: the sophisticated, sublime Dhamma among mankind.’

dn14:3.7.17.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mahābrahmā: ‘katāvakāso khomhi vipassinā bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammadesanāyā’ti vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tattheva antaradhāyi.
dn14:3.7.17.eng: Then the Great Divinity, knowing that his request for the Buddha Vipassī to teach the Dhamma had been granted, bowed and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

dn14:3.8.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa etadahosi:
dn14:3.8.1.eng: Then it occurred to the Blessed One Vipassī, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha,

dn14:3.8.2.pli: ‘kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ,
dn14:3.8.2.eng: ‘Who should I teach first of all?

dn14:3.8.3.eng: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’

dn14:3.8.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa etadahosi:

dn14:3.8.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho khaṇḍo ca rājaputto tisso ca purohitaputto bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā paṭivasanti paṇḍitā viyattā medhāvino dīgharattaṃ apparajakkhajātikā.
dn14:3.8.5.eng: ‘That Khaṇḍa, the king’s son, and Tissa, the high priest’s son, are astute, competent, clever, and have long had little dust in their eyes.
dn14:3.8.5.comm: In the account of Gotama, he first thinks to teach his former colleagues under whom he practiced the formless attainments. Here we see the start of a tendency in the legends of past Buddhas to erase the education among other spiritual teachers before awakening. Note that these two, who will become Vipassī’s chief disciples, are leading khattiya and brahmin sons of the royal household. Khaṇḍa was Vipassī’s brother, and the priest’s son was virtually family.

dn14:3.8.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ khaṇḍassa ca rājaputtassa, tissassa ca purohitaputtassa paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, te imaṃ dhammaṃ khippameva ājānissantī’ti.
dn14:3.8.6.eng: Why don’t I teach them first of all? They will quickly understand this teaching.’

dn14:3.9.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—bodhirukkhamūle antarahito bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā kheme migadāye pāturahosi.
dn14:3.9.1.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the tree of awakening and reappeared near the capital city of Bandhumatī, in the deer park named Sanctuary.
dn14:3.9.1.comm: Khema (“sanctuary”) originally meant “oasis”. It is common name for lakes and nature parks in the Jātakas.

dn14:3.9.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dāyapālaṃ āmantesi:
dn14:3.9.2.eng: Then the Buddha Vipassī addressed the park keeper,
dn14:3.9.2.comm: There is a clear distinction between such managed “parks” and wilderness regions (arañña).

dn14:3.9.3.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, samma dāyapāla, bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ pavisitvā khaṇḍañca rājaputtaṃ tissañca purohitaputtaṃ evaṃ vadehi—
dn14:3.9.3.eng: ‘My dear park keeper, please enter the city and say this to the king’s son Khaṇḍa and the high priest’s son Tissa:

dn14:3.9.4.pli: vipassī, bhante, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ anuppatto kheme migadāye viharati, so tumhākaṃ dassanakāmo’ti.
dn14:3.9.4.eng: “Sirs, the Blessed One Vipassī, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, has arrived at Bandhumatī and is staying in the deer park named Sanctuary. He wishes to see you.”’

dn14:3.9.5.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhante’ti kho, bhikkhave, dāyapālo vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa paṭissutvā bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ pavisitvā khaṇḍañca rājaputtaṃ tissañca purohitaputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn14:3.9.5.eng: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied the park keeper, and did as he was asked.

dn14:3.9.6.pli: ‘vipassī, bhante, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ anuppatto kheme migadāye viharati; so tumhākaṃ dassanakāmo’ti.

dn14:3.10.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, khaṇḍo ca rājaputto tisso ca purohitaputto bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni yojāpetvā bhaddaṃ bhaddaṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhaddehi bhaddehi yānehi bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā niyyiṃsu. Yena khemo migadāyo tena pāyiṃsu.
dn14:3.10.1.eng: Then the king’s son Khaṇḍa and the high priest’s son Tissa had the finest carriages harnessed. Then they mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out from Bandhumatī for the Sanctuary.

dn14:3.10.2.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikāva yena vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu. upasaṅkamitvā vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
dn14:3.10.2.eng: They went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha Vipassī on foot. They bowed and sat down to one side.

dn14:3.11.1.pli: Tesaṃ vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
dn14:3.11.1.eng: The Buddha Vipassī taught them step by step, with

dn14:3.11.2.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
dn14:3.11.2.eng: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.

dn14:3.11.3.pli: Yadā te bhagavā aññāsi kallacitte muducitte vinīvaraṇacitte udaggacitte pasannacitte, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi—
dn14:3.11.3.eng: And when he knew that their minds were ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, elated, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:

dn14:3.11.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

dn14:3.11.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
dn14:3.11.5.eng: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,

dn14:3.11.6.pli: evameva khaṇḍassa ca rājaputtassa tissassa ca purohitaputtassa tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
dn14:3.11.6.eng: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in the king’s son Khaṇḍa and the high priest’s son Tissa:

dn14:3.11.7.eng: ‘Everything that has a beginning has an end.’

dn14:3.12.1.pli: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn14:3.12.1.eng: They saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. They went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. They said to the Buddha Vipassī,

dn14:3.12.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: “cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī”ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn14:3.12.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

dn14:3.12.4.pli: Ete mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca.
dn14:3.12.4.eng: We go for refuge to the Blessed One and to the teaching.

dn14:3.12.5.pli: Labheyyāma mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyāma upasampadan’ti.
dn14:3.12.5.eng: Sir, may we receive the going forth and ordination in the Buddha’s presence?’

dn14:3.13.1.pli: Alatthuṃ kho, bhikkhave, khaṇḍo ca rājaputto, tisso ca purohitaputto vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike pabbajjaṃ alatthuṃ upasampadaṃ.
dn14:3.13.1.eng: And they received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha Vipassī’s presence.
dn14:3.13.1.comm: In the early period, there was no distinction between “going forth” (pabbajjā) and “ordination” (upasampadā). They refer to two sides of the same coin: leaving the home life and entering the ascetic life. Ordination was originally granted with the simple call, “Come mendicant!” (ehi bhikkhu).

dn14:3.13.2.pli: Te vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi;
dn14:3.13.2.eng: Then the Buddha Vipassī educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

dn14:3.13.3.pli: saṅkhārānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ nibbāne ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
dn14:3.13.3.eng: He explained the drawbacks of conditioned phenomena, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of extinguishment.

dn14:3.13.4.pli: Tesaṃ vipassinā bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammiyā kathāya sandassiyamānānaṃ samādapiyamānānaṃ samuttejiyamānānaṃ sampahaṃsiyamānānaṃ nacirasseva anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu.
dn14:3.13.4.eng: Being taught like this their minds were soon freed from defilements by not grasping.
dn14:3.13.4.comm: Thus they became arahants, realizing the same truth that Vipassī had.

dn14:3.14.0.eng: 14. The Going Forth of the Large Crowd

dn14:3.14.1.pli: Assosi kho, bhikkhave, bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā mahājanakāyo caturāsītipāṇasahassāni:
dn14:3.14.1.eng: A large crowd of 84,000 people in the capital of Bandhumatī heard

dn14:3.14.2.pli: ‘vipassī kira bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ anuppatto kheme migadāye viharati.
dn14:3.14.2.eng: that the Blessed One Vipassī, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, had arrived at Bandhumatī and was staying in the deer park named Sanctuary.

dn14:3.14.3.pli: Khaṇḍo ca kira rājaputto tisso ca purohitaputto vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā’ti.
dn14:3.14.3.eng: And they heard that the king’s son Khaṇḍa and the high priest’s son Tissa had shaved off their hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha’s presence.

dn14:3.14.5.pli: ‘na hi nūna so orako dhammavinayo, na sā orakā pabbajjā, yattha khaṇḍo ca rājaputto tisso ca purohitaputto kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā.
dn14:3.14.5.eng: ‘This must be no ordinary teaching and training, no ordinary going forth in which the king’s son Khaṇḍa and the high priest’s son Tissa have gone forth.

dn14:3.14.6.pli: Khaṇḍo ca rājaputto tisso ca purohitaputto kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissanti, kimaṅgaṃ pana mayan’ti.
dn14:3.14.6.eng: If even they go forth, why don’t we do the same?’

dn14:3.14.7.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mahājanakāyo caturāsītipāṇasahassāni bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā nikkhamitvā yena khemo migadāyo yena vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
dn14:3.14.7.eng: Then those 84,000 people left Bandhumatī for the deer park named Sanctuary, where they approached the Buddha Vipassī, bowed and sat down to one side.

dn14:3.15.1.pli: Tesaṃ vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi.
dn14:3.15.1.eng: The Buddha Vipassī taught them step by step, with

dn14:3.15.2.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
dn14:3.15.2.eng: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.

dn14:3.15.3.pli: Yadā te bhagavā aññāsi kallacitte muducitte vinīvaraṇacitte udaggacitte pasannacitte, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi—
dn14:3.15.3.eng: And when he knew that their minds were ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, elated, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:

dn14:3.15.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

dn14:3.15.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
dn14:3.15.5.eng: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,

dn14:3.15.6.pli: evameva tesaṃ caturāsītipāṇasahassānaṃ tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
dn14:3.15.6.eng: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in those 84,000 people:

dn14:3.15.7.eng: ‘Everything that has a beginning has an end.’

dn14:3.16.1.pli: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn14:3.16.1.eng: They saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. They went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. They said to the Buddha Vipassī,

dn14:3.16.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: “cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī”ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn14:3.16.3.eng: And just like Khaṇḍa and Tissa they asked for and received ordination. Then the Buddha taught them further.

dn14:3.16.4.pli: Ete mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.

dn14:3.16.5.pli: Labheyyāma mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ labheyyāma upasampadan’ti.

dn14:3.17.1.pli: Alatthuṃ kho, bhikkhave, tāni caturāsītipāṇasahassāni vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike pabbajjaṃ, alatthuṃ upasampadaṃ.

dn14:3.17.2.pli: Te vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi;

dn14:3.17.3.pli: saṅkhārānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ nibbāne ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.

dn14:3.17.4.pli: Tesaṃ vipassinā bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammiyā kathāya sandassiyamānānaṃ samādapiyamānānaṃ samuttejiyamānānaṃ sampahaṃsiyamānānaṃ nacirasseva anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu.
dn14:3.17.4.eng: Being taught like this their minds were soon freed from defilements by not grasping.

dn14:3.18.0.eng: 15. The 84,000 Who Had Gone Forth Previously

dn14:3.18.1.pli: Assosuṃ kho, bhikkhave, tāni purimāni caturāsītipabbajitasahassāni:
dn14:3.18.1.eng: The 84,000 people who had gone forth previously also heard:

dn14:3.18.2.pli: ‘vipassī kira bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ anuppatto kheme migadāye viharati, dhammañca kira desetī’ti.
dn14:3.18.2.eng: ‘It seems the Blessed One Vipassī, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, has arrived at Bandhumatī and is staying in the deer park named Sanctuary. And he is teaching the Dhamma!’

dn14:3.18.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tāni caturāsītipabbajitasahassāni yena bandhumatī rājadhānī yena khemo migadāyo yena vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
dn14:3.18.3.eng: Then they too went to see the Buddha Vipassī, realized the Dhamma, went forth, and became freed from defilements.

dn14:3.19.1.pli: Tesaṃ vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi.

dn14:3.19.2.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.

dn14:3.19.3.pli: Yadā te bhagavā aññāsi kallacitte muducitte vinīvaraṇacitte udaggacitte pasannacitte, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi—

dn14:3.19.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;

dn14:3.19.6.pli: evameva tesaṃ caturāsītipabbajitasahassānaṃ tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:

dn14:3.20.1.pli: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:

dn14:3.20.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: “cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī”ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.

dn14:3.20.4.pli: Ete mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.

dn14:3.20.5.pli: Labheyyāma mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ labheyyāma upasampadan’ti.

dn14:3.21.1.pli: Alatthuṃ kho, bhikkhave, tāni caturāsītipabbajitasahassāni vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike pabbajjaṃ alatthuṃ upasampadaṃ.

dn14:3.21.2.pli: Te vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi;

dn14:3.21.3.pli: saṅkhārānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ nibbāne ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.

dn14:3.21.4.pli: Tesaṃ vipassinā bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammiyā kathāya sandassiyamānānaṃ samādapiyamānānaṃ samuttejiyamānānaṃ sampahaṃsiyamānānaṃ nacirasseva anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu.

dn14:3.22.1.pli: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā mahābhikkhusaṅgho paṭivasati aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ.
dn14:3.22.1.eng: Now at that time a large Saṅgha of 6,800,000 mendicants were residing at Bandhumatī.

dn14:3.22.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
dn14:3.22.2.eng: As the Buddha Vipassī was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

dn14:3.22.3.pli: ‘mahā kho etarahi bhikkhusaṅgho bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā paṭivasati aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ, yannūnāhaṃ bhikkhū anujāneyyaṃ:
dn14:3.22.3.eng: ‘The Saṅgha residing at Bandhumatī now is large. What if I was to urge them:

dn14:3.22.4.pli: “caratha, bhikkhave, cārikaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ;
dn14:3.22.4.eng: “Wander forth, mendicants, for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
dn14:3.22.4.comm: As at Kd 1:11.1.4 and SN 4.5:2.3. One of the Buddha’s first acts is to empower his students.

dn14:3.22.5.eng: Let not two go by one road.

dn14:3.22.6.pli: desetha, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetha.
dn14:3.22.6.eng: Teach the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

dn14:3.22.7.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti,
dn14:3.22.7.eng: There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.

dn14:3.22.8.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!

dn14:3.22.9.pli: Api ca channaṃ channaṃ vassānaṃ accayena bandhumatī rājadhānī upasaṅkamitabbā pātimokkhuddesāyā”’ti.
dn14:3.22.9.eng: But when six years have passed, you must all come to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code.”’
dn14:3.22.9.comm: In the Vinaya of the current Buddha, the recitation occurs every fortnight on the uposatha (“sabbath”), and it includes only the mendicants resident in a specific monastery. Here they gathered from all over India.

dn14:3.23.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro mahābrahmā vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa purato pāturahosi.
dn14:3.23.1.eng: Then a certain Great Divinity, knowing the Buddha Vipassī’s train of thought, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha Vipassī.

dn14:3.23.2.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mahābrahmā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
dn14:3.23.2.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha Vipassī, and said,

dn14:3.23.3.eng: ‘That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

dn14:3.23.4.pli: Mahā kho, bhante, etarahi bhikkhusaṅgho bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā paṭivasati aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ, anujānātu, bhante, bhagavā bhikkhū:
dn14:3.23.4.eng: The Saṅgha residing at Bandhumatī now is large. Please urge them to wander, as you thought.

dn14:3.23.5.pli: “caratha, bhikkhave, cārikaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ;

dn14:3.23.7.pli: desetha, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetha.

dn14:3.23.8.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, bhavissanti dhammassa aññātāro”ti.

dn14:3.23.9.pli: Api ca, bhante, mayaṃ tathā karissāma yathā bhikkhū channaṃ channaṃ vassānaṃ accayena bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ upasaṅkamissanti pātimokkhuddesāyā’ti.
dn14:3.23.9.eng: And sir, I’ll make sure that when six years have passed the mendicants will return to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code.’

dn14:3.23.10.eng: That’s what that Great Divinity said.

dn14:3.23.11.pli: Idaṃ vatvā vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tattheva antaradhāyi.
dn14:3.23.11.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha Vipassī, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.

dn14:3.24.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bhikkhū āmantesi:
dn14:3.24.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha Vipassī came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants, telling them all that had happened. Then he said,

dn14:3.24.2.pli: ‘idha mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:

dn14:3.24.3.pli: “mahā kho etarahi bhikkhusaṅgho bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā paṭivasati aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ.

dn14:3.24.5.pli: caratha, bhikkhave, cārikaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ;

dn14:3.24.7.pli: desetha, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetha.

dn14:3.24.8.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, bhavissanti dhammassa aññātāro.

dn14:3.24.9.pli: Api ca channaṃ channaṃ vassānaṃ accayena bandhumatī rājadhānī upasaṅkamitabbā pātimokkhuddesāyā”’ti.

dn14:3.25.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro mahābrahmā mama cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito mama purato pāturahosi.

dn14:3.25.2.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mahābrahmā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yenāhaṃ tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā maṃ etadavoca:

dn14:3.25.4.pli: Mahā kho, bhante, etarahi bhikkhusaṅgho bandhumatiyā rājadhāniyā paṭivasati aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ.

dn14:3.25.6.pli: caratha, bhikkhave, cārikaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ;

dn14:3.25.9.pli: santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, bhavissanti dhammassa aññātāroti.

dn14:3.25.10.pli: Api ca, bhante, mayaṃ tathā karissāma, yathā bhikkhū channaṃ channaṃ vassānaṃ accayena bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ upasaṅkamissanti pātimokkhuddesāyā’ti.

dn14:3.25.12.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tattheva antaradhāyi.

dn14:3.26.1.pli: ‘Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, caratha cārikaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ;
dn14:3.26.1.eng: ‘Wander forth, mendicants, for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

dn14:3.26.2.eng: Let not two go by one road.

dn14:3.26.3.pli: desetha, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetha.
dn14:3.26.3.eng: Teach the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

dn14:3.26.4.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti,
dn14:3.26.4.eng: There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.

dn14:3.26.5.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!

dn14:3.26.6.pli: Api ca, bhikkhave, channaṃ channaṃ vassānaṃ accayena bandhumatī rājadhānī upasaṅkamitabbā pātimokkhuddesāyā’ti.
dn14:3.26.6.eng: But when six years have passed, you must all come to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code.’

dn14:3.26.7.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhū yebhuyyena ekāheneva janapadacārikaṃ pakkamiṃsu.
dn14:3.26.7.eng: Then most of the mendicants left to wander the country that very day.

dn14:3.27.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena jambudīpe caturāsīti āvāsasahassāni honti.
dn14:3.27.1.eng: Now at that time there were 84,000 monasteries in the Black Plum Tree Land.
dn14:3.27.1.comm: “Black Plum Tree Land” is jambudīpa, the South Asian subcontinent, including India, Pakistan, Nepal, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan. The number 84,000 does not seem excessive, as the Chinese pilgrims recorded many thousands of monasteries throughout India. In modern Thailand there are around 40,000 monasteries.

dn14:3.27.2.pli: Ekamhi hi vasse nikkhante devatā saddamanussāvesuṃ:
dn14:3.27.2.eng: And when the first year came to an end the deities raised the cry:

dn14:3.27.3.eng: ‘Good fellows, the first year has ended.

dn14:3.27.5.pli: pañcannaṃ vassānaṃ accayena bandhumatī rājadhānī upasaṅkamitabbā pātimokkhuddesāyā’ti.
dn14:3.27.5.eng: When five years have passed, you must all go to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code.’

dn14:3.27.9.eng: the fifth year came to an end, the deities raised the cry:

dn14:3.27.10.eng: ‘Good fellows, the fifth year has ended.

dn14:3.27.12.pli: ekassa vassassa accayena bandhumatī rājadhānī upasaṅkamitabbā pātimokkhuddesāyā’ti.
dn14:3.27.12.eng: When one year has passed, you must all go to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code.’

dn14:3.27.13.eng: And when the sixth year came to an end the deities raised the cry:

dn14:3.27.14.eng: ‘Good fellows, the sixth year has ended.

dn14:3.27.15.pli: samayo dāni bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ upasaṅkamituṃ pātimokkhuddesāyā’ti.
dn14:3.27.15.eng: Now is the time that you must go to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code.’

dn14:3.27.16.pli: Atha kho te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū appekacce sakena iddhānubhāvena appekacce devatānaṃ iddhānubhāvena ekāheneva bandhumatiṃ rājadhāniṃ upasaṅkamiṃsu pātimokkhuddesāyāti.
dn14:3.27.16.eng: Then that very day the mendicants went to Bandhumatī to recite the monastic code. Some went by their own psychic power, and some by the psychic power of the deities.

dn14:3.28.1.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bhikkhusaṅghe evaṃ pātimokkhaṃ uddisati:
dn14:3.28.1.eng: And there the Blessed One Vipassī, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, recited the monastic code thus:
dn14:3.28.1.comm: The verses that follow form the climax of the whole discourse. They are known as the Ovāda Pātimokkha, the “monastic code for exhortation”. It seems that they were recited on the uposatha in the days before the establishment of the list of rules that is also called pātimokkha. Most of the extant Vinayas still include these verses in the pātimokkha texts, the Pali being a notable exception.

dn14:3.28.2.comm: The Buddha redefines tapas from painful mortification to gentle acceptance.

dn14:3.28.3.eng: Extinguishment is the ultimate, say the Buddhas.
dn14:3.28.3.comm: These verses speak of “Buddhas” in plural.

dn14:3.28.5.eng: nor does an ascetic hurt another.

dn14:3.28.6.comm: These famous lines serve as a succinct summary of the entire Buddhist path.

dn14:3.28.7.comm: “Embrace” is upasampadā, to “enter into”. It is the same word used for taking ordination as well as entering jhāna.

dn14:3.28.9.eng: this is the instruction of the Buddhas.
dn14:3.28.9.comm: The buddhasāsana (“instruction of the Buddha” or “dispensation of the Buddha”) is the normal word used by Buddhists to refer to their own religion.

dn14:3.28.10.eng: Not speaking ill nor doing harm;

dn14:3.28.11.comm: Here “monastic code” means the principles outlined in these verses. They are spelled out in more detail in the Gradual Training (DN 2, etc.), and ultimately in the detailed legal code of the Vinayapiṭaka.

dn14:3.28.14.comm: The “higher mind” is the four jhānas (AN 3.90:3.2).

dn14:3.28.15.eng: this is the instruction of the Buddhas.’

dn14:3.29.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhikkhave, samayaṃ ukkaṭṭhāyaṃ viharāmi subhagavane sālarājamūle.
dn14:3.29.1.eng: This one time, mendicants, I was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree.
dn14:3.29.1.comm: The Buddha now returns to the present life. Ukkaṭṭhā is the home of Pokkharasāti (DN 3:2.13.1) and the site of the astonishing and cosmically significant discourses MN 1 and MN 49.

dn14:3.29.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
dn14:3.29.2.eng: As I was in private retreat this thought came to mind,

dn14:3.29.3.pli: ‘na kho so sattāvāso sulabharūpo, yo mayā anāvutthapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehi.
dn14:3.29.3.eng: ‘It’s not easy to find an abode of sentient beings where I haven’t previously abided in all this long time, except for the gods of the pure abodes.
dn14:3.29.3.comm: Only non-returners are born in the pure abodes (suddhāvāsā), from where they realize full awakening.

dn14:3.29.4.eng: Why don’t I go to see them?’

dn14:3.29.5.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—ukkaṭṭhāyaṃ subhagavane sālarājamūle antarahito avihesu devesu pāturahosiṃ.
dn14:3.29.5.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, I vanished from the Subhaga Forest and reappeared with the gods of Aviha.

dn14:3.29.6.pli: Tasmiṃ, bhikkhave, devanikāye anekāni devatāsahassāni anekāni devatāsatasahassāni yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhikkhave, tā devatā maṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn14:3.29.6.eng: In that order of gods, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of deities approached me, bowed, stood to one side, and said to me,
dn14:3.29.6.comm: “Order of gods” is devanikāya. I use “deity” to distinguish devatā from deva but there is no substantial difference.

dn14:3.29.7.pli: ‘ito so, mārisā, ekanavutikappe yaṃ vipassī bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
dn14:3.29.7.eng: ‘Ninety-one eons ago, good fellow, the Buddha Vipassī arose in the world, perfected and fully awakened.

dn14:3.29.8.pli: Vipassī, mārisā, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho khattiyo jātiyā ahosi, khattiyakule udapādi.
dn14:3.29.8.eng: He was born as an aristocrat into an aristocrat family.

dn14:3.29.9.pli: Vipassī, mārisā, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho koṇḍañño gottena ahosi.

dn14:3.29.10.pli: Vipassissa, mārisā, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asītivassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.

dn14:3.29.11.pli: Vipassī, mārisā, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pāṭaliyā mūle abhisambuddho.
dn14:3.29.11.eng: He was awakened at the root of a patala tree.

dn14:3.29.12.pli: Vipassissa, mārisā, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa khaṇḍatissaṃ nāma sāvakayugaṃ ahosi aggaṃ bhaddayugaṃ.
dn14:3.29.12.eng: He had a fine pair of chief disciples named Khaṇḍa and Tissa.

dn14:3.29.13.pli: Vipassissa, mārisā, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ. Eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṃ. Eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi bhikkhusatasahassaṃ. Eko sāvakānaṃ sannipāto ahosi asītibhikkhusahassāni. Vipassissa, mārisā, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ime tayo sāvakānaṃ sannipātā ahesuṃ sabbesaṃyeva khīṇāsavānaṃ.
dn14:3.29.13.eng: He had three gatherings of disciples—one of 6,800,000, one of 100,000, and one of 80,000—all of them mendicants who had ended their defilements.

dn14:3.29.14.pli: Vipassissa, mārisā, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asoko nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
dn14:3.29.14.eng: He had as chief attendant a mendicant named Asoka.

dn14:3.29.15.pli: Vipassissa, mārisā, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bandhumā nāma rājā pitā ahosi.

dn14:3.29.16.pli: Bandhumatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
dn14:3.29.16.eng: his birth mother was Queen Bandhumatī,

dn14:3.29.17.pli: Bandhumassa rañño bandhumatī nāma nagaraṃ rājadhānī ahosi.
dn14:3.29.17.eng: and their capital city was named Bandhumatī.

dn14:3.29.18.pli: Vipassissa, mārisā, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa evaṃ abhinikkhamanaṃ ahosi evaṃ pabbajjā evaṃ padhānaṃ evaṃ abhisambodhi evaṃ dhammacakkappavattanaṃ.
dn14:3.29.18.eng: And such was his renunciation, such his going forth, such his striving, such his awakening, and such his rolling forth of the wheel of Dhamma.
dn14:3.29.18.comm: This is a list of the major events in any Buddha biography.

dn14:3.29.19.pli: Te mayaṃ, mārisā, vipassimhi bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ caritvā kāmesu kāmacchandaṃ virājetvā idhūpapannā’ti …
dn14:3.29.19.eng: And good fellow, after leading the spiritual life under that Buddha Vipassī we lost our desire for sensual pleasures and were reborn here.’
dn14:3.29.19.comm: The lifespan in such a realm can be many hundreds of eons.

dn14:3.29.20.eng: And other deities came and similarly recounted the details of the Buddhas Sikhī, Vessabhū, Kakusandha, Koṇāgamana, and Kassapa.
dn14:3.29.20.comm: These are absent in the Pali text at this point, but they are mentioned below, and the commentary says they should be included here.

dn14:3.30.1.pli: Tasmiṃyeva kho, bhikkhave, devanikāye anekāni devatāsahassāni anekāni devatāsatasahassāni yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhikkhave, tā devatā maṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn14:3.30.1.eng: In that order of gods, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of deities approached me, bowed, stood to one side, and said to me,

dn14:3.30.2.pli: ‘imasmiṃyeva kho, mārisā, bhaddakappe bhagavā etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho loke uppanno.
